Quinn has a PhD in Human Geography from University College Dublin .", 'She currently lectures and research in the Department of Tourism at the Dublin Institute of Technology .', 'The nature and meaning of festival and festivity in contemporary society is one of her key research interest and her work on the topic has been published in a number of international journal including Urban Studies , Social and Cultural Geography , Tourism Geographies , Event Management and the Journal of Policy Research in Tourism , Leisure and Event .', 'Other research interest include the relationship between culture and tourism , leisure and social inclusion and contemporary form of tourism mobility .', 'Publication on these topic have appeared in the Annals of Tourism Research , Gender , Place and Culture and Leisure Studies as well as in various edited book collection .', 'Her teaching interest mirror her research interest and she is involved in undergraduate and postgraduate tourism management and event management programme teaching module related to cultural tourism , international festival environment , tourism study , and tourism and event policy.AcknowledgementsMy long-standing interest in festival and event has been shaped by many people , both practitioner and academic , over the year .', 'These people are too many to mention by name , but I owe all of them a debt of gratitude .', 'While writing this book I was very fortunate to be able to draw on the expertise of colleague , particularly Lucy Horan and Ruth Craggs , as well as the support and encouragement of my other colleague at the Dublin Institute of Technology .', 'Finally , a huge thank you to John , Muireann and Aoife for absolutely everything.IntroductionIn 1991 , Getz wrote that festival and holiday event represented nouveau , alternative tourism ( cited in Lee et al.', ', 2008 ) .', 'How time have changed !', 'Such an assertion is simply unimaginable today when , more than 20 year later , finding a city or town without at least one annual festival or planned event would be quite a challenge .', 'Does this constitute progress ?', 'How do festival and event contribute to contemporary society ?', 'What has the remarkable rise in festival and event meant for the development of tourism destination ; for the development of economy , be they local , national or international ?', 'These and many other question preoccupy what is now an extremely large , international community of scholar from a range of discipline who adopt a variety of research approach to study the complex and profoundly important communal celebration at the heart of the diverse festival and event treated in this volume.While it is difficult to calculate the size of festival and event activity , academic , policy and industry commentator everywhere concur that its recent growth across the world in term of number , diversity and popularity has been enormous ( Getz , 1991 ; Finkel , 2009 ; Thrane , 2002 ) .', 'In the USA it is estimated that there were 10,000 festival per year , attracting over 31 million visitor by the mid-1990s ( Janiskee , 1996 ; TIA , 2004 ) .', 'In Australia , the government notes that festival have become ubiquitous , with hundred being held every year ( Australian Government , 2012 ) .', 'In Europe , the growth has been similarly dramatic .', 'According to the International Festival and Event Association ( IFEA ) , the special event industry is estimated to comprise between 4 and 5 million regularly occurring event ( Wood , 2012 ) .', 'This significant growth in the practice of festival and event brought a parallel increase in the emergence and development of the festival and event management profession .', 'It soon also brought a rise in academic interest : closely allied to the development of tourism study , academic began to take an interest in charting development in the sector and the literature has burgeoned over the last 20 year .', 'Much of the research is published in tourism study and specific event-oriented journal , but it also finds expression in a wide range of journal dedicated to management and marketing , urban and place study , art and cultural policy , as well as many social sciences-oriented journal .', 'In the majority of case , festival and special event are presented as broadly positive phenomenon .', 'Throughout the literature , opening paragraphs emphasise the important role they play in advancing local and regional economy , branding place , attracting visitor , extending the tourism season and fostering community spirit .', 'Yet , festival and special event , the subject matter at the heart of this book represent a very substantial , complex and dynamic set of activity that can be both deeply rooted and rapidly changing in country throughout the world .', 'In academia , they are studied from diverse management , social science and humanity perspective .', 'As such , interpretation of their impact and contribution to contemporary economy and society as well as approach to valuing , managing and shaping appropriate policy for their advancement are multiple and at time conflicting.The literature in the field is now enormous and growing all the time .', 'Increasing familiarity with the literature brings an increasing awareness of the unevenness of knowledge , the fracture between academic discipline and the continuous emergence of new sub-fields .', 'The literature on the Olympic Games , for example , is now in and of itself very substantial , yet the extent to which knowledge generated on this particular event translates across into the study of other event that differ by scale and type is very unclear .', 'Getz and Andersson ( 2010 ) explained that festival tourism has been studied by many researcher from many perspective : impact ( of varying type ) , place marketing , travel pattern , displacement effect , motivation , market segmentation , quality and satisfaction , regional development , relationship to urban renewal and development , and link to culture and community .', 'However , this sector is nothing if not dynamic and while knowledge gap are closing in some area , they continue to open up elsewhere all the time .', 'This book tries to take cognisance of this dynamism in including concept that would seem very important in term of future development .', "The concept of ‘ risk management ' , so important from an applied perspective , and that of ‘ emerging economy ' , so important from a geographical perspective , are two example of this.This volume is tasked with introducing , defining and reviewing the current state of knowledge of the key concept in the contemporary study of festival and event .", 'While this involves reviewing literature that is either part of , or closely associated with , tourism study , in reality , it is a multi-disciplinary task that draws on a wide breadth of discipline area .', 'It is well recognised that festival and special event are important from community , social , cultural , political and economic perspective .', 'Despite the growth and popularity of festival and special event , researcher were initially slow in directing research beyond economic impact and motivation ( Gursoy et al.', ', 2004 ) .', 'However , this imbalance is now being corrected .', 'The recent evolution of the academic study of festival and event can not be understood in isolation from the simultaneous evolution of the academic study of tourism .', 'As theme of enquiry have emerged and developed within tourism study , they virtually always evolve into a new theme of enquiry within festival and event study .', 'This link between the two area of study is very strong , with tourism study the primary field of enquiry and festival and event a large and distinct sub-field within.The task of advancing knowledge about the meaning , practice and policy associated with festival and event remains ongoing .', 'As this volume will show , the understanding of core concept remains uneven , and our knowledge of certain dimension of festival and event activity far exceeds that of others .', 'Some of the extant gap are recent , emerging only when contemporary political and societal debate begin to highlight particular concern .', 'The concept of innovation is a case in point : question as to the role that the festival and event sector plays in promoting , adopting and managing innovation are now coming to the fore in the literature .', "Others , such as the sustainability of the sector 's activity have been an issue for longer .", 'Most recently of all , the question as to how festival and event activity are affected by global recession has begun to be investigated , in response to the harsh reality negatively affecting the health of the sector in very recent time .', 'The 35 concept that are discussed in this volume are laid out in alphabetical order .', 'Mobility and market research : Outdoor advertising and the commercial ontology of the city .', 'This article explores the centrality of mobility in the practice of the outdoor advertising industry , analysing how commercial conceptualisation of mobility orient the production and sale of advertising space on roadside billboard , panel in pedestrian zone , on bus and taxis , and in train station .', "I explore how the industry 's market research practice conceive of urban space as mobility , and how understanding of mobility impact upon the design of advertising structure and their textual content .", 'I conceptualise as a retroduction the relationship between market research practice , the aesthetic of advertising design and the visual engagement of people with advertisement .', 'This is a performative relationship that produces a commercial ontology of the city .', 'These retroductive relationship do not merely reproduce the hegemony of an urban commodity culture ; they open up alternative way of knowing the city .', 'Population and climate change .. To review , the four broad dimension of any complex human problem , including climate change , are the human population , economics , culture , and environment .', 'These dimension interact with one another in all direction and on many time-scales .', 'From 2010 to 2050 , the human population is likely to grow bigger , more slowly , older , and more urban .', "It is projected that by 2050 more than 2.6 billion people ( almost 94 % of global urban growth ) will be added to the urban population in today 's developing country .", "That works out to 1.26 million additional urban people in today 's developing country every week from 2010 to 2050 .", 'Human alter the climate by emitting greenhouse gas , by altering planetary albedo , and by altering atmospheric component .', "Between 1900 and 2000 , human ' emission of carbon into the atmosphere increased fifteenfold , while the number of people increased less than fourfold .", 'Population growth alone , with constant rate of emission per person , could not account for the increase in the carbon emission to the atmosphere .', 'The world economy grew sixteenfold in the twentieth century , accompanied by enormous increase in the burning of gas , oil , and coal .', 'In the last quarter of the twentieth century , population grew much faster in developing country than in high-income country , and , compared with population growth , the growth of carbon emission to the atmosphere was even faster in developing country than in high-income country .', 'The ratio of emissions-to-population growth rate was 2.8 in developing country compared with 1.6 in high-income country .', 'Emission of CO2 and other greenhouse gas are influenced by the size and density of settlement , the size of household , and the age of householder .', 'Between 2010 and 2050 , these demographic factor are anticipated to change substantially .', 'Therefore demography will play a substantial role in the dynamic of climate change .', 'Climate change affect many aspect of the living environment , including human settlement , food production , and disease .', 'These change will affect poor people more severely than rich , and poor nation more severely than rich .', 'Yet not enough is known to predict quantitatively many detail that will matter enormously to future people and other specie .', 'Three kind of response are related to demographic issue that affect climate change : universal secondary education , voluntary contraception and maternal health service , and smarter urban design and construction .', 'These response may prevent , reduce , or ameliorate the impact of climate change .', 'They are as relevant to rich country as to poor , though in way that are as different as are rich country and poor .', 'They are desirable in their own right because they improve the life of the people they affect directly ; and they are desirable for their beneficial effect on the larger society and globe .', 'They are effective response to the twin challenge of reducing poverty and reducing greenhouse gas emission .', 'Geography of protest : Place of demonstration in Buenos Aires and Seoul .', 'Demonstration shape the urban landscape and affect the normal function of a city .', 'They disrupt traffic , make marginalized people and neglected area visible in city center , and challenge élite design of urban landscape both visually and functionally .', "Demonstration question élite norm by using city space in nonconformist way for making claim , and by charging place with demonstrator ' own meaning .", 'Difference between Buenos Aires and Seoul show that historically developed convention and symbolic reading of city space matter in the strategic choice of place to protest .', 'Yet most demonstration site belong to the same major category .', 'Demonstrator may gather outside governmental building to communicate with the authority ; at center of commercial activity to appeal to the public ; to place that link them historically , culturally or morally with symbolically important event ; or at place connected with a particular grievance .', 'Along with local tradition , an internationally shared demonstration culture determines what kinds of place are suitable for demonstration .', 'Blue urbanism : Exploring connection between city and ocean .', 'What would it mean to live in city designed to foster feeling of connectedness to the ocean ?', 'As coastal city begin planning for climate change and rising sea level , author Timothy Beatley sees opportunity for rethinking the relationship between urban development and the ocean .', 'Modern society is more dependent upon ocean resource than people are commonly aware of , from oil and gas extraction to wind energy , to the vast amount of fish harvested globally , to medicinal compound derived from sea creature , and more .', "In Blue Urbanism , Beatley argues that , given all we 've gained from the sea , city policy , plan , and daily urban life should acknowledge and support a healthy ocean environment .", 'The book explores issue ranging from urban design and land use , to resource extraction and renewable energy , to educating urbanites about the wonder of marine life .', "Beatley looks at how emerging practice like `` community supported fishery '' and aquaponics can provide a sustainable alternative to industrial fishing practices.Other chapter delve into incentive for increasing use of wind and tidal energy as renewable option to oil and gas extraction that damage ocean life , and how the shipping industry is becoming more `` green . ''", 'Additionally , urban citizen , he explains , have many opportunity to interact meaningfully with the ocean , from beach cleanup to helping scientist gather data .', "Ultimately , he explains that we must create a culture of `` ocean literacy '' using a variety of approach , from building design and art installation that draw inspiration from marine form , to encouraging citizen volunteerism related to ocean , to city-sponsored research , and support for new law that protect marine health .", 'Equal part inspiration and practical advice for urban planner , ocean activist , and policymakers , Blue Urbanism offers a comprehensive look at the challenge and great potential for urban area to integrate ocean health into their policy and planning goal .', "Producing and consuming the painter Raphael 's birthplace .", "Purpose – The purpose of this paper is to draw upon Johnson 's “ Circle of Culture ” to develop a cultural approach for studying place marketing 's internal audience .", 'A research project on the small Italian Renaissance city of Urbino explores how a number of marketing event dedicated to the painter Raphael , who was born there , have been produced and then received among different urban “ population ” ( dweller , commuter , student , etc . )', '.', "The second part of the paper conceptualizes event as both “ inward ” and “ outward ” force and compares the Raphaellian event with some of Urbino 's traditional festivity .", 'Design/methodology/approach – This is a qualitative study that applies discourse analysis to medium text , official document and 42 in-depth interview held with both local official and internal place consumer .', 'Finding – The inquiry reveals a predominance of discourse in support of the event : civic pride , identification , and economic benefit .', "What is more striking is that some participant not only appreciated the marketing event but “ went beyond ” by producing discourse in support of a more intensive exploitation of Urbino 's cultural and heritage resource .", 'Research limitations/implications – Quantitative research is recommended to generalize evidence stemming from ethnographic inquiry and to measure “ the magnitude ” of the different discourse produced by the people .', 'Originality/value – This paper contributes to overcoming the materialist perspective which underpins a consistent part of literature by showing a new ( counter ) example of the “ non-oppositional voice ” of place marketing .', 'Moreover , it sheds more light on how “ tertiary communication ” takes place and how it can be properly investigated .', 'Planning for sustainable urban area or everyday life and inclusion .', 'This paper discusses the extent to which the diversity and equality agenda is being taken into account at street level as planner and urban designer seek to create sustainable settlement .', 'The paper argues that many design policy inspired by the sustainability agenda do not take into account inclusive urban design consideration , and thus large sector of the population are adversely affected .', 'While attention is given to the need of the disabled , particular emphasis is put in this paper upon the design need of woman and older people who together compose around a third of the population .', 'The impact of compact layout and higher density in residential area is first discussed , along with the problem created by increased car control , without commensurate transport policy alternative , or adequate , safe pedestrian routeways .', 'Second the problem of city centre are discussed where sustainability policy is also being targeted , but other priority including the new urbanism , the 24-hour city , the evening economy and the city of culture jostle for pre-eminence .', "It is concluded that the lack of awareness of people 's need and inclusive design principle are reducing the chance of ordinary people accessing , comfortably moving around and enjoying the city .", 'In order to bridge the gap between sustainability and inclusive design in planning , it is concluded that greater emphasis must be given to user need and the constraint of everyday life .', 'Town planning in postcolonial India , 1947-1965 : Chandigarh re-examined .', 'The objective of this article is to reassess the new town building movement in India from 1947 to 1965 through a re-examination of the making of Chandigarh , to show how nationalism , modernism , and local regional influence affected the design and building of new town .', 'Chandigarh emerged as part of the post-Partition need for a new capital for the Punjab , and involved the effort of several people and level of government .', 'The context of newly achieved nationhood became important in the way it shaped the ideal of both national and local political leader , who wanted architect to transfer these into built form .', 'How successful the architect were in this enterprise was shaped by their professional ideology and understanding ( or lack of it ) of the local .', "Much scholarship exists on issue such as early decision about Chandigarh 's establishment , the Mayer and Le Corbusier plans for the city , and the building comprising the Capitol complex that were designed by Le Corbusier .", 'Much less attention has been given to the residential area of Chandigarh and all that lay beyond the Capitol complex and constitutes the actual town .', 'How did the idea of modernism , the requirement of the nationalist state , and concern for the local shape the built environment ?', 'Was a Western urban design simply replicated here or were there modification to suit locality and culture ?', 'Study on building plan for enhancing the social health of public apartment .', "Mass-produced in a short period of time , Korea 's public apartment contributed to easing the housing anxiety of the common people .", 'Nonetheless , they also gave rise to problem of social exclusion and conflict , becoming undesirable facility that weakened social health .', 'This study examined way of producing an improved building plan that can raise the level of social health of public apartment , which were consistently built in the past but will no doubt continue to be developed in the future .', 'For this study , the survey method was employed through a questionnaire with visual content especially developed to raise the level of social health based on two idea .', 'One was to increase the possibility of social interaction among resident , and the other was to increase opportunity for resident to interact with society as well as for their social integration .', 'The result showed that resident had mostly favorable view on the proposed plan : in particular , they favored highly the formation of a lobby in each apartment building as a venue for social interaction .', 'They also responded very favorably to the plan of creating within the building spare space that will be used not only to promote a communal culture , but to open to outside society as well for integration .', 'This study showed vital idea to ensure the recovery of the residential function of promoting social health in the public apartment of Korea .', 'It has significance in inspiring an innovative approach to allow social mixture in a relatively different feasible manner from the conventional approach .', 'How to manage Urban school district .', 'One of the biggest management challenge anywhere is how to improve student performance in urban public school in the United States .', 'There has been no shortage of proposed solution : Find great principal and give them power ; create competitive market with charter , voucher , and choice ; establish small school to ensure that student receive sufficient attention-the list goes on .', 'Although these approach have created positive change in individual school , they have failed to produce a single high-performing urban school system .', "In this article , the author , who are member of Harvard University 's Public Education Leadership Project ( PELP ) , explain why .", 'One reason , they say , is that educator , researcher , and policy maker see the district office , which oversees all the school in a district , as part of the problem rather than a crucial part of the solution-and this is a mistake .', 'The district office plays an important role in developing strategy , identifying and spreading best practice , developing leadership capability at all level , building information system to monitor student improvement , and holding people accountable for result .', 'The author propose a holistic framework that district leader can use to develop an improvement strategy and build coherent organization to implement it .', 'The framework is based on three belief .', 'First , school system need their own management model ; they can not simply import them from the business world .', "Second , `` the customer '' is the student ; therefore , urban district need to focus on improving teaching and learning in every classroom at every school .", 'Third , district leader must design their organization so that all the components-culture , system and structure , resource , and mechanism for managing stakeholder and the external environment-reinforce one another and support the implementation of the strategy across school .', 'Street and social life in city : a taxonomy of sociability .', 'Evident in the urban revival of North American city are planning and design strategy focused on attracting the downtown worker , the tourist , the conventioneer and the newly implanted suburbanite .', 'In this wave of revival , many group are marginalized , the reclaimed public space is often sanitized , gentrified and fortified , and not inclusive .', 'However , there are urban public space that defy or at least resist these trend .', 'Examining urban neighbourhood main street reveals that even though the contemporary urban street can never be an unregulated place of unconstrained diversity , there are street that counter the prevalent culture of consumption , and one can find visible sign of spontaneity and diversity of people and activity , and genuine social life .', 'Using research in urban sociology , a taxonomy for sociability is developed , and the existing range of classification of outdoor social activity is expanded .', 'Through empirical examination , this paper explains how these street perform as social spaces—how sociability is enacted , and what is the nature of planning , design and management , which supports social behaviour .', 'Finally , the research emphasizes the role of the street as an ordinary public space in creating affordances for everyday social contact that are crucial to personal well-being and social cohesion .', 'Acculturation research critique and alternative research design .', 'Dictionary definition concur that “ acculturation ” means second-culture acquisition , but “ acculturation ” began as a Eurocentric concept that inferior people improve themselves by imitating superior people .', 'Shadow of this persist despite the acceleration of acculturation research from nine study per decade in the 1920s to the current rate of more than 6000 per decade .', 'Review of this research have noted confused finding and lack of utility .', 'Critic either ( 1 ) advocate for qualitative method because culture , identity , and human experience are too complex for psychometric method , or ( 2 ) recommend new model and new form of quantitative analysis , or ( 3 ) fault research for poor social science practice .', 'Rudmin ( 2006 ) has argued that academic ’ shared liberal ideology cause collective confirmation bias that shapes research to promote advocacy of bicultural integration .', 'Many future research design and project are proposed , including emic study of rural-urban migration in China and the development of single-case measure of acculturative competence .', 'Seeking abundance : Consumption as a motivating factor in city past and present .', 'Purpose : This paper utilizes the perspective of abundance , rather than scarcity , to understand economy of city .', 'It also proposes that the earliest urban center were attractive place of settlement because they represented a greater variety of job and object compared to the rural countryside .', 'Design/methodology/approach : The evolutionary trajectory of our specie indicates that human sought out abundance in their natural environment as early as a million year ago .', "People also deliberately replicated condition of abundance through the manufacture and discard of large quantity of repetitive object , and through the `` waste '' of usable good .", 'The development of urban center 6,000 year ago provided new opportunity for both production and consumption and an abundance of diverse good and service .', "These process are analogous to contemporary economist ' view of abundance as a desirable principle and Chris Anderson 's view of the Long Tail as the explanatory mechanism for the production and consumption of good when greater distribution becomes possible .", 'Social implication : Today , city are growing very rapidly despite objectively deleterious condition such as crowding , pollution , competition , and disease transmission .', "By recognizing the `` pull '' factor of consumption and opportunity , researcher can expend their energy to mitigate the negative effect of city ' inevitable growth .", "Originality/value : Prior archaeological and contemporary analysis of city have focused on the role of the upper echelon of the political and economic hierarchy ; in contrast , this `` bottom-up '' approach addresses the attraction of city from the perspective of ordinary inhabitant .", 'Hong Kong architecture 1945-2015 : From colonial to global .', 'This book focuses on the transformation from colonial to global - the formation , mechanism , event , work and people related to urban architecture .', 'The book reveals hardships the city encountered in the 1950s and the glamour enjoyed in the 1980s .', 'It depicts the public and private development , and especially the public housing which has sheltered million of resident .', 'The author identifies the architect practising in the formative year and the representative of a rising generation after the 1980s .', 'Suffering from land shortage and a dense environment , the urban development of Hong Kong has in the past 70 year met the changing demand of fluctuating economic activity and a rising population .', 'Architecture on the island has been shaped by social demand , the economy and technology .', 'The building have been forged by the government , client , planner , architect , many contractor and end-users .', 'The built environment nurtures our life and is visual evidence of the way the city has developed .', 'Hong Kong is a key to East Asia in the Pacific Era .', 'The book is a must-read for a thorough understanding the contemporary history and architecture of this oriental pearl .', 'Endorsement : `` Hong Kong sets an extreme example of hyper-density living .', 'MTR ’ s Kowloon Station project offered my firm the unique opportunity to contribute to a new type of fully integrated three dimensional transport mega-structure , conceived as a well-connected place for people to live , work and play .', "Through Charlie Xue ’ s book , one can see how a compact city work and high density integrated development indicates a sustainable path for modern city making . ''", "Sir Terry Farrell , CBE , Principal , Farrells `` Well researched and refreshingly well structured , Charlie Xue ’ s latest book comprehensively shows how Hong Kong ’ s post-war urban architecture both track and symbolizes the former British colony ’ s rise to success - a must read for architecture and culture buff alike . ''", 'Peter G. Rowe , Raymond Garbe Professor of Architecture and Urban Design , Harvard University Distinguished Service Professor .', '`` An essential addition to the growing literature on Chinese architecture , the title of the book belies the full scope of Xue ’ s extensive history .', 'Covering Hong Kong ’ s postwar transition from defeated colony to Pacific Age power house , Xue expertly traces the evolution of the city ’ s ambitious and innovative program of integrated high density urban design and infrastructure , as well as changing architectural fashion .', "In a time when many Western government have all but abandoned public housing program , Xue ’ s book is a timely reminder of what can be achieved . ''", 'Professor Chris Abel , author of Architecture and Identity , Architecture , technology and process and The Extended Self .', 'Festival connection : How consistent and innovative connection enable small-scale rural festival to contribute to socially sustainable community .', 'Purpose : The purpose of this paper is to examine the contribution of small-scale , rural festival to the social sustainability of their host community .', 'Small-scale , community originated festival proliferate the rural landscape throughout the UK and yet despite this , festival research has focussed predominantly on large , urban event and on their economic impact ( Wood , 2009 ; Gibson and Connell , 2011 ) .', 'This paper seeks to address the perceived research gap by examining these event through a lens of social sustainability .', 'Design/methodology/approach : The research uses a case study approach focussed on four festival in Northumberland , UK .', 'Individual interview and focus group were conducted with festival organiser , key figure and visitor .', 'Following a constructivist grounded theory method four principle indicator were identified to determine festival contribution to community social sustainability .', 'These indicator are : contribution to community pride and localness , enhancement of knowledge and understanding , contribution to the continuity of local culture and enablement of network of connectivity .', 'Finding : The finding demonstrate the network of connection which festivals enable between the culture , heritage and people ( individual and group ) of a place .', 'By focussing on four indicator the paper shows the social impact of connection through the festival processes and content .', 'The paper argues that small-scale festival in rural location can contribute to social sustainability if they demonstrate a balance of both consistency and innovation and accessibility and openness within the locale .', 'Originality/value : This paper addresses the gap in social impact research into rural festival and present an original approach to identify festival impact on community social sustainability .', 'Country-of-origin and emerging country : Revisiting a complex relationship .', 'Purpose – The purpose of the current study is to attempt to contribute to the understanding of some socio-cultural factor likely to explain the preference for international product in emerging country , and more specifically those characterising former colonised country in the Middle East and North Africa.Design/methodology/approach – The chosen approach is exploratory and of a qualitative inductive nature .', 'It was based on a series of semi-structured and unstructured in-depth interview with Tunisian consumer about their relationship to local and foreign products.findings – A set of complex and inter-related explanatory factor of the country-of-origin phenomenon emerged through the analysis , notably the complex of the decolonised , acculturation in situ , frustration towards the West and sensitivity to the Western fashion system.Research limitations/implications – The main limitation of this research is that the interview were carried out among people living in the three main city of Tunisia , which are urban settings.Practical implication – This research proposes a general framework and a set of new construct that may be used by leader of business , communication agency or distribution company .', 'These element may help them for segmentation , assortment and range decision , and brand names.Social implication – Given the failure of “ buy local ” campaign , this research shows the importance to revive Tunisian consumer ’ feeling of identification with their local culture and to reconcile them with their own identity .', 'Suggestion are given to reach these objectives.Originality/value – This research proposes a framework explaining how the country-of-origin effect in emerging country operates in a different manner from what has been suggested in the study conducted in Western contexts .', 'Visual pollution : Advertising , signage and environmental quality .', 'In recent year , there has been considerable interest in the problem that public space face because of the design of commercial sign .', "The negative consequence that commercial sign can have on the visual quality of urban area and further more , on people 's quality of life , has been studied from both architectural , planning and psychological perspective .", 'While the issue of visual pollution , as this phenomenon is commonly described , has been widely debated , there is as yet no clear conclusion as to how best to control commercial signage and whether different urban contexts and people from different background and culture have universal or distinct preference .', 'Several different commenrcial signage approach are currently applied to different historic city , but these initiative are not based on principle derived from the perception and evaluation of user .', 'Drawing on a range of comparative and contrasting empirical study of historic city centre in the UK and Brazil , this book examines question of commercial signage control management , the preservation of historic heritage and user preference and satisfaction .', 'The author takes an environment behaviour approach to this research , involving theory , concept and methodology related to environmental psychology , architecture , planning and urban design .', 'In doing so , it argues that there are in fact visual preference common to the majority of people , independent of their urban context and that these common view can be useful to the development of a general theory of how to control commercial signage .', 'In conclusion , the book suggests that the best way of controlling signage is not only to recommend general guideline related to the operation of commercial signage , but also to recommend design principle that can create commercial streetscapes evaluated positively by different user .', 'Aquifer system response to intensive pumping in urban area of the Gangetic plain , India : The case study of Patna .', 'A significant component of domestic demand for water of urban area located in the Gangetic plain is met by heavy pumping of groundwater .', 'The present study is focused on the Patna municipal area , inhabited by 17 million people and spanning over 134 km2 , where entire urban water demand is catered from pumping by well of various capacity and design .', 'The present study examines the nature of the aquifer system within the urban area , the temporal change in the water/piezometric level and the recharge mechanism of the deeper aquifer .', 'The aquifer system is made up of medium-to-coarse unconsolidated sand , lying under a ~40-m-thick predominantly argillaceous unit holding 8- to 13-m-thick localised sand layer and continues up to 220 m below ground .', 'Groundwater occurs under semi-confined condition , with transmissivity of aquifer in 5,500-9,200 m2 day-1 range .', 'Hydraulic head of the deeper aquifer remains in 9-19 m range below ground , in contrast to 1-9 m range of that of the upper aquitard zone .', 'The estimated annual groundwater extraction from the deeper aquifer is ~212.0 million m3 , which has created a decline of 3.9 m in the piezometric level of the deeper aquifer during the past 30 year .', 'Unregulated construction of deep tube well with mushrooming of apartment culture may further exacerbate the problem .', 'The sand layer within the aquitard zone are experiencing an annual extraction of 14.5 million m3 and have exhibited stable water level trend for past one and half decade .', 'This unit is recharged from monsoon rainfall , besides contribution from water supply pipe line leakage and seepage from unlined storm water drain .', 'Modernism , modernization and post-colonial India : A reflective essay .', 'As a result of political change stemming from independence and partition , India was forced to build new state capital and add extension to existing city to provide home to refugee , house state government , and deal with urban congestion .', 'Although the British had built New Delhi as the new capital of the Raj at the beginning of the twentieth century , there were hardly any trained Indians to undertake the task of planning and architecture .', 'While British India had done a remarkable job in educating Indians in liberal art and law , it had done very little to promote discipline such as engineering , architecture and technical education .', 'The development of Chandigarh , Bhubaneswar and Gandhinagar , between 1949 and 1982 , represents a fascinating study of practical politics , personal ambition of politician and Western planner , and the high ideal of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru .', 'The architect-planner Le Corbusier , together with Nehru , provided the new planning model and architectural design that would overshadow imperial New Delhi .', 'Chandigarh was to serve as a training school for Indian planner , who could then duplicate their experience in other city to improve urban India , and also influence rural India .', 'The story of Chandigarh , Bhubaneswar and Gandhinagar is not one of success or failure or even of comparative satisfaction with the quality of life in a new city .', 'It is , rather , a chronicle of a period during which India made a bold attempt to make a break with her past within the confines of a socio-urban experiment that included , along with an innovative master plan , modernist building , new land-use pattern , provision for education , recreation , medical and social service , the careful and deliberate inclusion of idea that had their origin in a culture far removed from her own .', 'Between the idea of the planner and hope of the government official there lies a narrative of planned city and the people who inhabit them , and the influence of modernism on India generally .', 'This paper reflects on the impact of modernist architecture on India .', 'Monumentalizing the everyday : The Edo-Tokyo museum .', 'The Edo-Tokyo Museum is both the crowning achievement of the populist historiography of Edo-Tokyo study and the monumental embodiment of an era of cultural nationalism in Japan .', 'It embodies the perennial tension between the city as home to a unique local culture and the city as a site of state power .', 'The historian who oversaw the design of the exhibit envisioned a celebration of local everyday life , and focused their effort on narrating the history of a mythic urban folk .', "A critical walk through the museum reveals three fundamental mode of mythic projection that underwrote this folk narrative : the city of the past as a `` world we have lost , '' commonplace tool as icon of an essential native culture resisting modernization , and the modern century as a march of progress in everyday life , indexed by ever-improving commodity .", "Throughout this narrative , the protagonist are the `` ordinary people '' ( shomin ) of Edo-Tokyo .", "In contrast , the building 's architect saw the city solely in term of its national significance and sought to project an image of grandeur suited to the position of Japan as triumphant superpower .", 'No conflict was recognized between the two seemingly contradictory impulse , however , since myth of the everyday , exploited by government as well as academic in these year , promoted the easy fusion of local and national narrative .', 'Community Operational Research : Developing a systemic peace education programme involving urban and rural community in Colombia .', 'This paper describes a Community Operational Research inquiry in which member of diverse local and marginalised community , working with external researcher , created a peace programme that was implemented in more than four hundred and fifty local school .', 'It has disseminated a culture of peace in a social context characterised by high level of violence .', 'Diverse systemic problem structuring method were used throughout the development of the programme .', 'The creative design of method guided the research and contributed to develop an evolving , participative multimethodology that mixes method and tool from the qualitative/quantitative spectrum , including interactive planning , critical system heuristic , soft system methodology , statistic , and method from the conflict resolution field .', 'The peace programme was initially designed using a synergy of problem structuring method , and several tool and method were used thereafter to improve the programme as its contexts evolved .', 'Community operational research and system thinking have had an impact on the programme since its initial stage , and have contributed to modify it based on well-grounded quantitative and qualitative information .', 'This programme has reached more than a million people in Colombian society , and has been internationally recognised as one of the most innovative and impacting experience for Latin American social development .', 'It has created a culture of peace in hundred of school , having transformative effect on the individual as well as on their social relation .', 'Moreover , the impact of the programme has transcended the school ’ boundary and has spread to wider circle of society .', 'Urban infrastructure as materialized consensus .', 'Abstract : Infrastructure that shape and facilitates daily life , such as pathway , conduit and boundary wall , constitutes one of the most dynamic form of architecture in both ancient and modern city .', 'Although infrastructure is conceived and designed with particular goal and capacity , its temporal and spatial scale means that it is a constant work in progress that engages numerous agent : civic authority design and implement infrastructure ; designated agency maintain and repair infrastructure ; and ordinary people utilize , modify , ignore or destroy it .', 'Infrastructure can be thus analyzed as a materialization of ongoing communication , in which there are often conflicts among different constituent to achieve consensus .', 'The linguistic concept of expert language and turn-taking are utilized to assess three brief case study : historical New Orleans ; a multipurpose micro-park in Vienna , Austria ; and the archaeological city of Sisupalgarh , India .', 'Peasant on display : The Czechoslavic ethnographic exhibition of 1895 .', 'In the increasingly modernized Central Europe of the late nineteenth century , folk culture , with its alleged ancient character , was still understood by some scholar as the bearer of national identity .', 'The Czechoslavic [ sic ] Ethnographic Exhibition , which took place in Prague in 1895 , aimed to promote the idea of the ethnically unified , but at the same time regionally diverse , identity of the Czech-speaking people living in Bohemia , Moravia and Slovakia .', 'Having to negotiate their identity with the ethnic Germans of Bohemia , the Czechs consciously excluded them from the event both as organizer and as exhibitor .', 'The exhibition could therefore be seen as a symptom of its time - in the late nineteenth century Central Europe , locating national heritage was crucial and folk culture played an important role in the national politics , and not only for the Czechs .', "This article focuses mainly on the ethnographic exhibit entitled 'the Exhibition Village ' , which consisted of an eclectic selection of village house and their imitation from Bohemia , Moravia and Slovakia .", 'On this basis , it explores the political intention behind the display of folk culture to both urban and rural audience and brings attention to the question of integration of the diverse regional object in a utopian national whole .', 'The article thus also aims to demonstrate issue related to the use of folk artefact for the purpose of cultural nationalism in Austria-Hungary in the late nineteenth century .', 'Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of The Design History Society .', "Towards modern urban housing : Redefining Shanghai 's lilong .", "This paper examines both the traditional and the modern aspect of the lilong , traditional low-rise row house adapted from the Western tradition to accommodate the family of Chinese worker from the beginning of the Treaty Port era in the late 19th century to the establishment of the People 's Republic in 1948 .", 'The paper aims to redefine the abstract concept of the lilong , arguing for their potential to be rethought as a typology of low–medium rise-high density ( LMRHD ) housing today .', 'In particular , the paper delivers a practical answer to a conceptual question : how does lilong provide the dwelling identity of Shanghai , China , taking into account its form , meaning , and culture ?', 'The emergence of both lilong and Western modern housing is rooted in a crisis of space and the economic drive of modern city .', 'Lilong architecture and the normative living programme embedded in the typology of modern housing have been proper development housing strategy in modern Shanghai .', 'By closely examining both the physical and community aspect that make lilong a mediating agency between Chinese locality and Western modernity , the paper presents the assumption that the architecture of lilong does not confine itself to certain form or physical configuration ; instead it is an “ abstract concept ” of an urban neighbourhood–the spatial organization , architectural practicality , casual formation of semi-private space , and community lane-life–a concept that should be taken into account for the design of urban housing today .', "The redefinition of lilong is a conceptual idea that will serve as a point of departure for the last part of the paper : a discussion of the possibility to develop this housing strategy for today 's situation .", 'This paper also presents the preliminary strategy for the designing of the new LMRHD housing .', 'Market place , social space in Cuzco , Peru .', 'The author argues that spatial relation are critical to explaining the nature of economic , social , and activity .', 'The article finally turns to the bitter political contestation among resident , vendor and municipal authority over market space .', 'The diverse tactic that vendor have developed to defend themselves incorporate their knowledge of urban spatial relation , gender and racial ideology , the physical body itself , and legal measure .', "Money and commodity ... were destined to bring with them not only a 'culture ' but also a space .", 'The uniqueness of the marketplace , doubtless on account of the splendor of religious and political structure , has tended to be overlooked .', 'We should therefore remind ourselves that antiquity looked upon trade and trades-people as external to the city , as outside its political system , and so relegated them to the outskirt .', 'The basis of wealth was still real property , ownership of the land .', 'The medieval revolution brought commerce inside the town and lodged it at the center of a transformed urban space .', "The marketplace differed from the forum as from the agora : access to it was free , and it opened up on every side onto the surrounding territory ... and into the countryside 's network of road and lane .", "[ The market hall 's ] function was to shelter the transaction of business while permitting the authority to control it .", 'The cathedral church was certainly not far away , but its tower no longer bore the symbol of knowledge and power ; instead the freestanding campanile now dominated space , and would soon , as clock-tower , come to dominate time too ... exclusively agropastoral , and where consequently no commercial activity was as yet taking place ( Lefebvre 1991 : 265 ) .', 'The role of fluctuating soundscapes in shaping the emotional geography of irregular sound ) .', 'Located in the subfield of ‘ emotional geography ’ , the paper discusses how participant were forced to connect with and attune to previously unremarkable aspect of their inform conscious acoustic design effort that respect the ‘ ear and voice ’ of people living with varying level of auditory sensitivity , rather than urban and community planning policy that continue .', 'Participant .', 'Thirty-five people ( 74.3 % female , 71.4 % aged 25-64 year ) across the four community .', 'Method .', 'PhotoVoice activity occurred over 3 month during the spring of 2009 .', environment .', 'Strategy should also account for the beautification and maintenance of community , increasing feeling of safety , enhancement of social support among community member , popularization of PA , and mitigating car culture , among others .', "Forest fire ' impact on tourism development : A comparative study of Greece and Cyprus .", 'Purpose : Every year thousand of acre are burned and society and lower impact on the environment are the main outcome of a concerted communication campaign .', 'Tourism represents and multiplies the image of the country as a whole to the world ; a catastrophe in Cyprus and Greece .', 'The outcome of the interview is presented for the first time .', 'Introduction modern architecture and the middle east : The burden of representation .', 'The essay in this volume investigate the contribution that local Middle Eastern context make to discourses in international modernism .', 'The essayist define modernization not only as the extension of industrialized building process and urban infrastructure , but also as the spread of ideal of progress and standard of comfort-which is to say , modernization is the ideology as well as the built framework for the administration of industrial society .', 'Architecture can help consolidate identity by providing both a degree of social cohesion and iconic form that can become a source of pride for community .', 'Yet , for others , such architectural form can become stereotype that flatten culture into amere sign.Throughout these essay , one discerns an abiding concern for question of representation , for how building and monuments-or in some case , the lack of them- acquiremeaning , harden conviction , and set the spatial infrastructure for subsequent generation .', 'The Middle East , with its diverse social , religious , and national history , has often been seen by architect and academic as rich in traditional architecture but poor as a resource for understanding the Modern period .', 'European have idealized the Middle East as an almost timeless place , a region that stands in distinct and didactic contrast with the disruptive displacement and disillusionment that has resulted from its own industrialization.1 These essay describe the unique way by which Middle Eastern country have invented their own version of modernism , sometimes aligned and sometimes at odds with more familiar European version , and in varying relation with larger pattern of imperialism and colonialism .', 'When individual designer and decision maker crossed national border to build or to learn , to provide aid or extract resource , as architect , teacher , or tourist , the dichotomy of modern-traditional orWestern-Eastern did not truly hold .', 'Our goal here is to build into the study of transnational architectural exchange the widest consideration of constituency and the most extended opportunity for input.contributors examine awide range of cultural encounter in term of institutionalization of relationship , dynamic interaction of bureaucratic structure , and pattern of patronage amid debate over design and urban planning .', 'Even local history aremultiple , often disputed in their formation , and inevitably shifting over time .', 'Taken together , they illustrate the various strategy that set national policy and decidewho is housed and who goes wanting , who is remembered and who is forgotten , and who is empowered to remake the built landscape .', 'Several essay profile the individual who helped realize certain specificallyMiddle Eastern form of modernity .', 'Some of them , such as European art historian and expatriate architect and archeologist , positioned themselves as the arbiter of Western knowledge , while others were seen as importingWestern ideal and technology to theMiddle East .', 'In other case , institution , such as government or development agency , assumed these role .', 'In many instance , however , cultural authority was as much a matter of dynamic transition in political or architectural sympathy as it was the result of official credential .', 'These essay call attention to circuit of intention and response , which inflamed allegedly objective depiction of technological progress into heated debate regarding the nature of modernity itself .', 'Modernism and the Middle East contextualizes the challenge facing building effort today by placing themwithin a larger historical trajectory stretching from colonialism and the rise of nation-states to the present postcolonial search for local identity.By detailing howarchitecture has been integral to complex political ambition and economic program , the contributor make evident the historical role played by competing vision of the built environment , as form of representation and as ameans of directing capital and labor flow .', 'With such attention to its deep tradition and rapidmodernization , the Middle East emerges as a rich setting for the study of modern architecture .', 'Modernism and the Middle East begins at the cusp of the twentieth century amid the decline of colonialism and the rise of independent nation-states in region once ruled by theottomans ( r. 1290-1924 ) in present-day Turkey and North Africa , and the Qajars ( r. 1779-1924 ) in Iran ( see fig .', "I.1 ) .2 Under the dynastic leadership of the Sultan , overseer of the holy site of Mecca andMedina and the supreme ruler of the Sunni Islamic world , the relatively stable and unified Ottoman Empire had administeredmuch of today 's Middle East .", 'But this administrative unity and geographic cohesion was eroded greatly during the nineteenth century , and it dissolved completely in the twentieth.3 Beyond the actual loss of land , Ottoman rule was disrupted by major infrastructure development , most notably the Suez Canal ( 1854-69 ) , which brought French and , later , English capital and technology to Egypt.4 By the twilight of World War I , in 1918 , Istanbul had itself come under Allied control , and the six-hundred-year-oldOttoman Empire came to an end , its former land divided into area administered by the French ( Syria and Lebanon ) and the British ( Iraq and Palestine ) .5 Even as newnations emerged with at least nominal sovereignty from the Mandate period , the idea of a coherent , if not exactly cohesive , Middle East was reinforced .', 'The Mandates carved new political entity , such as Palestine and Iraq , out of former Ottoman administrative zone , but it kept these nation from being fully independent , and left them wanting in term of industrial development .', 'At the same time , European occupation sparked nationalist movement in neighboring Turkey and Iran , resulting in the overthrow of puppet monarchy and the rise of charismatic military leader , who threwoff century of imperial rule and modernized in the name of national progress .', 'The advent of Mustafa Kemal in Turkey ( 1919 ) and Riza Khan in Iran ( 1921 ) brought new mode of judicial and educational reform ( often based on European model ) , in an effort to forge homogeneous , if fictive , native identities.6 The characterization of entire people by their position along the trajectory of history and modernization was asmuch embraced by regional leader as it was imposed by European power and ideology .', 'Oil came to be written into this idea of a cohesive Middle East as much by its discovery there as by the increasing industrial thirst for source of fuel .', 'The image of Arab state unified by ocean of oil lying unseen beneath their soil emerged in the nineteenth centurywith the advent of a British-controlled Anglo-Persian oil company .', 'It was extended as new field were discovered , such as those in Iraq in the 1930s and those in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia by 1945 .', "With the institution of the American 's Marshall Plan ( 1948-52 ) , the European economy was reconfigured according to American precept , resulting in an emphasis on continued growth in productivity and an even greater dependence on oil .", 'The Middle East thus moved to the center of foreign-policy strategy for a number of Western nation , becoming also a site of contentious ideological positioning between the Soviet Union and the United States , with both nation acting out their political difference through technical aid and development project as well as cultural export .', 'Although some small Persian Gulf monarchy enjoyed considerable advantage over their oil-poor neighbor , towesterners the regionmaintained its conceptual integrity as a site of superpower struggle and vast economic opportunity.7 The creation of the state of Israel , on May 14 , 1948 , also helped consolidate an idea of the Middle East , albeit in a way unanticipated by mostWestern politician .', "Although Jewish immigration to the area in the first half of the twentieth century had profoundly accected the economic and demographic character of Mandate Palestine , the United Nations ' 1947 plan to partition the area into Jewish and Arab state , whichwas rejected by the Arab League , formed in 1945 , seemed only to reassert Western colonialism at the very moment it was breaking apart elsewhere .", 'Within this context , theMiddle Eastmust be historically situated as a place defined both by European colonial interest and by the specific imperial configuration that had existed in the region .', "Just as the specter of essentialism hovers over the term `` Middle East , '' one may argue that it also haunts the idea of a homogeneous `` Europe '' ; nonetheless , as Dipesh Chakrabarty has argued in another context , these term highlight , rather than obfuscate , the problematic of domination and intellectual dependency that permeates any discussion of these two entities.8 The interdependency of Europe and the Middle East can be seen in the unfolding of an `` Oriental '' supplement to European identity : what was understood by nineteenth-century policymakers as the `` Eastern question '' had to do less with the inhabitant of these region than with the raw currency of human labor and material wealth promised through imperialism .", 'Separation , emulation and competition : Hybridization style of management culture in Thailand , Mexico and Israel .', "Purpose - The paper 's aim is to show three different manager ' story .", 'Finding - The paper provides data of the style of hybridization of management produced by local manager in Thailand , Mexico , and Israel of two global corporation headquartered senior manager with academic degree in engineering or business , and they manage highly trained worker .', 'The cultural processes this paper develops are most applicable to people like those interviewed Practical implication - Recognizing the style of hybridization shown in this paper can be of assistance for global corporation in setting the condition not only for the transfer but also for the appropriate integration and adaptation of their management value and practice to the local .', "Originality/value - The paper suggests seeing local manager of global corporation as acknowledgeable agent who do not absorb the corporation ' management form as they are but use different style to integrate them in their own .", 'Scottish café society : Contemporary consumption issue dominance of Scottish pub culture , indicates potential decline and further gender segregation at a time when company are trying to involve the family more in the public house market .', 'Originality/value - This paper will be of interest to anyone who has pondered life over a cup of designer coffee in or from a branded outlet and wondered whatever one did before the advent of this this perspective .', 'Thing American : Art museum and civic culture in the progressive era .', '`` Thing American gives us , at last , a history of the Metropolitan Museum of Art based on genuine archival material .', 'Moreover , it reorients our thinking about art museum in the United States , demonstrating that there were important democratic , utilitarian , and civic impulse at work behind them .', 'The book also broadens our thinking about progressivism , reminding us how it shaped art museum and how those museum-related program it spawned continued beyond World War I .', '`` -Steven Conn , author of Do Museums Still Need Objects ?', 'American art museum of the Gilded Age were established as civic institution intended to provide civilizing influence to an urban public , but the parochial worldview of their founder limited their democratic potential .', 'Instead , critic have derided nineteenth-century museum as temple of spiritual uplift far removed from the daily experience and concern of common people .', 'But in the early twentieth century , a new generation of cultural leader revolutionized idea about art institution by insisting that their collection and gallery serve the general public .', 'Thing American : Art Museums and Civic Culture in the Progressive Era tells the story of the civic reformer and art professional who brought museum from the realm of exclusivity into the progressive fold of library , school , and settlement house .', "Jeffrey Trask 's history focuses on New York 's Metropolitan Museum of Art , which stood at the center of this movement to preserve artifact from the American past for social change and Americanization .", 'Metropolitan trustee Robert de Forest and pioneering museum professional Henry Watson Kent influenced a wide network of fellow reformer and cultural institution .', 'Drawing on the teaching of John Dewey and close study of museum development in Germany and Great Britain , they expanded audience , changed access policy , and broadened the scope of what museum collect and display .', 'They believed that tasteful urban and domestic environment contributed to good citizenship and recognized the economic advantage of improving American industrial production through design education .', 'Trask follows the influence of these people and idea through the 1920s and 1930s as the Met opened its innovative American Wing while simultaneously promoting modern industrial art .', 'Thing American is not only the first critical history of the Metropolitan Museum .', 'The book also places museum in the context of the cultural politics of the progressive movement-illustrating the limit of progressive idea of democratic reform as well as the boldness of vision about cultural capital promoted by museum and other cultural institution .', 'Jeffrey Trask teach at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst .', 'Virtual study abroad and exchange studio .', 'The digital design studio has an area of 'Design of sustainable relief housing in Ethiopia : An implementation of cradle to cradle design in earthbag construction .', 'Problem statement : Urbanization in Ethiopia resulted in urban poverty and homelessness .', 'In this study , a sustainable relief housing prototype that aided in sheltering homeless citizen was designed .', 'To avoid repeating error in urban development such as unsustainable resource consumption , it was necessary to look beyond traditional construction material and method .', 'Approach : This design applied cradle to cradle design model to the earthbag construction technique and developed a prototype for sustainable relief housing in Ethiopia .', 'Result : Based on environmental and human health , all material selected for construction were naturally occurring and could safely return to nature after use .', 'Structural design maximized natural energy use and housing and interior design considered the local culture in Ethiopia .', most effective use of material resource , no synthetic material and toxin deposition and the best indoor air quality for human health .', 'Using earthbags rather than wood for the structure , this housing design helped prevent deforestation and the resulting desertification in Ethiopia .', 'The Role of the Built Environment in Human Life .', 'Selected Issue .', 'Creation of the built
