challenged people and brings the knowledge by other mean than formula and number .', 'This information carries a strong potential that could be used by architect and urban planner when designing building or urban public place according to inclusive design principle .', 'Latina woman and political leadership : Implication for latino community empowerment .', 'Most study of political leadership reflect certain assumption about how leadership is conceptualized , who is counted as a leader , and how leadership should be studied .', 'Some of these assumption seem to tie leadership to holding office or position in organization ; others focus on the personal trait of the people who are leader .', 'Still others seem to conceive of leadership as the ability to contribute to a cause , organization , or process and focus on the effectiveness of different leadership strategy or style .', 'Finally , there are assumption that lead to an examination of the relationship between leader and his or her follower .', 'All of these assumption inform both the research design and the conclusion reached about political leadership .', 'However , it is not untypical for a study built on one type of assumption about leadership to ignore the other dimension that form the totality of leadership in urban politics today .', 'Although it is not without value to select a narrow aspect of a field to study , what seems to be occurring in the area of political leadership is a certain blindness as to how the implicit or at least unstated assumption reflect bias about culture and gender .', 'Engineering design , project management , and community service connected through servant leadership .', 'Servant-Leadership is a leadership paradigm that emphasizes power sharing in decision making process .', 'It also encourages leader to serve those they manage by propelling them toward high achievement while promoting their professional growth and self-efficacy .', 'Servant-Leadership is also being pioneered as a teaching pedagogy at the Milwaukee School of Engineering , an approach that is unique because most academic institution subscribe instead to the service-learning model .', 'In conventional academic setting , instructor are the authority figure with control over content , knowledge , assessment , and course outcome .', 'By contrast , servant-leadership place instructor at the bottom of an inverted power pyramid where they provide a supportive foundation for the student above them .', 'The author hypothesize that this supportive structure lends itself ideally to faculty mentorship of engineering design-and-build project ; for example capstone senior design project .', 'In well-managed student project , faculty member do none of the actual design or construction work .', 'Instead , they mentor a team of student toward successful completion of the challenge .', 'To evaluate the impact of a servant-leadership teaching pedagogy in an engineering setting , an interdisciplinary faculty collaboration was implemented that combined three component : 1 ) a curriculum-integrated design-and-build project ; 2 ) an industrial engineering project management course ; are highly valued in promoting student recruiting .', "Within one faculty member 's quarter-long senior-level mechanical engineering thermodynamics course , student designed , built , tested , and deployed three miniature aquaponic demonstration unit for the Sweet Water Foundation ( SWF ) , a Milwaukee-based non-profit organization .", 'The SWF mission is to teach the public about sustainable urban agriculture .', "The project 's mechanical engineering ( ME ) student were supported by student taking an industrial engineering ( IE ) project management course from a different faculty member .", 'IE student served as project manager .', 'Simultaneously , a third faculty member , expert in implementing servant-leadership as a teaching pedagogy , secured project funding from the Brady tremendous change in the early twenty-first century .', 'Similarly , the landscape of music delivery and discovery is drastically evolving because of new technology .', 'This paper presents SoundAbout , a platform for location-based music service .', 'It enables new application running on mobile phone and desktop .', 'It allows user to share music and information about music they listened to in city during a particular time span , select a list of favourite artist or song and attach that list in favourable location , and see who else in different location share their taste in music .', 'Our goal is to not only support musical serendipity , but also affect the city culture .', 'With context-aware music service , it is possible to offer people new kind of urban audio experience .', 'In this paper , we apply characteristic of psychogeography and graffiti painting as an inspiration for the design of service concept for the platform .', "A neighborhood in Singapore : Ordinary people 's life downstairs .", 'In this chapter,1 my focus is the activity and experience of the ordinary people of Singapore , the vast majority ( 85 % ) of whom live in public housing estate built by the state Housing and Development Board ( HDB ) .', 'Through anthropological observation of their activity and experience ( 1988-1989 and regularly since 1992 ) in everyday life and special occasion in one such public housing estate named Marine Parade,2 I show and discuss the following : 1 ) the living diversity of culture in various public space within the local public housing community ; and 2 ) some ethnic , multiethnic and multicultural aspect and issue among those who inhabit , define , negotiate , administer and control these space and the complex relationship involved .', 'Through example and illustration , I also show that material can be drawn from it to reflect , interpret and symbolize diverse group and culture and their relation .', "In the public-private housing divide that has come to characterize Singapore class society , public housing resident are commonly viewed as that homogeneous lot of `` heartlanders '' ( as opposed to `` cosmopolitan '' ) who live in `` pigeonhole '' in uniform and unaesthetic high-rise block of flat in somewhat `` inauthentic '' community .", 'What I show and discuss is how ordinary people go about their life meaningfully both because of and despite the planned housing environment , contrary to the common view that such an environment that has replaced the older village or urban street settlement is standard , sterile and starved of spontaneous , organic and interesting life .', 'My focus on people as active agent in their ordinary life also offers insight into living culture as part of Singapore and its experience , place-making3 and heritage , beyond those of old buildings/sites , design and built environment which currently tend to dominate in local heritage discourse .', "In doing so , I hope to show the contribution of the city 's ordinary citizen to its evolution which have thus far tended to escape the planner , critic or outsider with top-down , selective or superficial view of the city and the world of its ordinary people .", 'Georgian Bay , Muskoka , and Haliburton : More than cottage country ?', '.', "The mere mention of `` cottage country '' anywhere in Canada almost inevitably conjures up image of Ontario 's forested lakeland .", 'This chapter explores the georegion stretching from Georgian Bay eastward to Haliburton and the Algonquin Highlands and from the French River southward to the Trent-Severn waterway and the Oak Ridges Moraine .', 'Although permanently if sparsely settled since the early nineteenth century , it is widely considered a summer leisure destination , and indeed it is now dominated by second home numbering in the ten of thousand .', 'Resident of major city in the lower Great Lakes basin have extended their everyday life-spaces to include its waterfront setting for over a century .', 'What once were modest summer cottage are increasingly elaborate permanent dwelling occupied part-time by Greater Toronto Area resident , entrenching the quasi-suburban role of this georegion .', "This chapter highlights the confluence of abiotic , biotic , and cultural component in the Georgian Bay , Muskoka , and Haliburton georegion , suggesting how its hybrid cultural-natural ecology stem from its transitional qualities-both symbolically , as an exurban cultural `` edge '' to the Toronto-centred metropolis , and functionally , in geophysical term .", "Contemporary Ontario folklore tell us that the province contains a space known as `` cottage country '' -a swath stretching from Georgian Bay through Muskoka into Haliburton and the Kawartha Lakes .", 'History shows that this space is more than a hinterland of second home for an increasingly ( sub ) urban society .', 'However , at various juncture in human history it has been the home territory and hunting ground for various aboriginal group , a place of ruthless resource extraction , and ( with varying degree of success ) an agricultural area .', 'As a georegion , it is a compelling case study in the confluence of abiotic , biotic , and cultural forces-the ABC paradigm that underlies the case study in this volume .', 'This chapter traces how these force have generated a hybrid of cultural-natural ecology in this georegion .', "We pay close attention to the georegion 's transitional quality .", 'This is true both symbolically-for this area has become an exurban cultural edge to the Toronto-centred metropolitan region-and functionally , in term of its geology and ecology , since it straddles the transition from the arable St Lawrence Lowlands to the rocky Canadian Shield , with its proliferation of freshwater lake .', "By markedly shaping settlement possibility and pattern , this `` edge '' has also tended to be self-reinforcing .", 'It has embedded itself in the materiality of its own cultural landscape .', "Its haunting beauty and ruggedness , in concert with the Anglo-American compulsion to `` escape '' the city , have , moreover , elevated part of central Ontario to near-mythic status as the very archetype of a summer playground .", 'In this chapter , we present the Georgian Bay/Muskoka/Haliburton georegion through a summary of its physiographic and ecosystem characteristic , along with an account of its human settlement and activity pattern over the past several thousand year .', "We also introduce a set of critical argument concerning what this `` cottage country '' georegion now is and what it represents in the Anglo-American world .", 'Key question are presented as we trace social history from the earliest human settlement through European colonization and the late-nineteenth-century rise of large-scale tourism .', 'Of particular interest is how this georegion has come to be uniquely replete with saleable landscape commodity in the form of waterfront or wateroriented second home , most of which have been built , owned , and used by city dweller .', 'Of course , other region in Ontario , across North America , and around the world are also strongly marked by the presence of second home .', 'Yet in this area these waterfront settlement patterns represent an especially characteristic intersection of abiotic , biotic , and cultural layer of the landscape of the georegion of which they are part .', 'They are not the only distinguishing feature , but they are extremely salient .', "We suggest way in which the curious blend of abiotic , biotic , and cultural force in this georegion can offer hope for the contemporary challenge of getting people to understand the links between `` nature '' and `` culture '' in human settlement system .", 'Our chapter therefore culminates with a set of comment for planning and design practice .', "Back to the future : ethnodevelopment among the Jalq ' a of Bolivia ..", "The story is told of how several out about `` potolo '' weaving .", "The Jalq ' a people were found in number totaling 25,000 impoverished and with very high infant mortality rate , low income , and social disorganization .", 'although the traditional woven dress were still worn , the color combination and motif had lost their originality and precision .', 'The story was told about how during the 1960s and 1970s the poor cash economy had forced people to sell their textile to tourist and trader for lower than market value .', 'Eventually it became apparent that there were no longer model of the traditional garment to inspire new generation .', 'Upon the anthropologist arrival and inquiry , it was related that local interest to revive production of these native textile was still there .', 'The craft revival took root because of the interest in the people not just as artisan but as people , and rapport was established .', 'The background of the anthropologist is related .', 'A grassroots support organization ( GSO ) was formed to assist in economic development that was rooted in the life of the community .', 'The pace was set by participant and a few woman at first were trained in commercial production .', conserve their language and culture and textile .", 'New workshop were blessed in a similar way .', "In the first workshop the challenge was for the woman to determine how to make the many strange animal that appeared in Jalq ' a design ; a photographic archive was put together and the hand-dyed color restored with some difficulty .", "The exhibit of the textile after several year led to new respect for the Jalq ' a and indigenous people and a means of recognition for further sale .", "Women 's status and Irupampa socioeconomic status has improved ; migration to urban area has been slowed .", "The experience of the Navajo in the US has been helpful in the Jalq ' a effort in international marketing .", 'GSO has been able to provide guidance to others in learning about their spinning machine , quality control system , and marketing strategy .', 'Association of psychosocial and perceived environmental factor with park-based physical activity among elderly in two city in China and Germany .', 'Background : Urban park play an important role in promoting physical activity ( PA ) among adult and especially among older city resident .', 'According to the socioecological approach the association of physical environment and psychosocial factor in the context of park-based PA of elderly have not been systematically examined until now , let alone the relevance of the city ( urban area ) on a cross-cultural level .', 'This study investigated selected aspect of ( 1 ) the association of psychosocial and park environmental factor with park-based physical activity ( PBPA ) of older people ; and ( 2 ) the moderating effect of city on the association of these factor with PBPA .', 'Method : A face-to-face survey was conducted of a mixed-culture sample from different urban surroundings in Hong Kong ( HK ) and Leipzig ( L ) .', 'In six park of each city physically active elderly ( > = 60 year ; HK : n = 306 ; L : n = 311 ) were recruited .', 'Multiple linear regression were used to analyse the association between psychosocial factor and perceived environmental factor with PBPA and the moderating effect of city .', 'Result : Controlled for demographic variable , all other psychosocial factor were significantly related to PBPA , except social support .', 'In term of environmental factor , PBPA was positively associated with safety , attractiveness , feature and negatively associated with park time distance .', 'Controlled for demographic variable , psychosocial and environmental factor , the moderating effect of city on the association of park feature and park time distance with PBPA was not significant in HK .', 'In contrast , there was a significant positive relationship for park feature and a negative relationship for park time distance with PBPA in L. Conclusions : Psychosocial and perceived environmental factor significantly influence PBPA of older people .', 'City moderates the association of these factor and independently contributes to park-based PA of the elderly .', 'The different interaction of environmental factor and urban area for PBPA of elderly can support policy maker on the municipal level in choosing adequate strategy for promoting PA of older people in park .', 'Codesign of public space for intercultural communication , diversity and inclusion .', 'The consistent phenomenon of immigration from country with different competence from design , business , engineering and social science to find innovative solution for the social inclusion of migrant in urban area .', 'Suggesting theoretical urban neighborhood design concept by adopting the changing discourse of social capital .', 'Purpose : The purpose of this paper is to review , analyze and synthesize different piece from literature to explore , define and describe the concept of social capital and its relationship with urban neighborhood design concept .', 'Additionally , to define the indicator and principle that can enhance social capital within urban design context .', 'Moreover , to suggest theoretical urban neighborhood design concept that can adopt the changing discourse of social capital .', 'Design/methodology/approach : This research used the theoretical , analytical and descriptive approach-driven case study method .', 'In all , 29 paper were analyzed to conclude the indicator that can measure social capital within the urban neighborhood design context and to conclude the required neighborhood design feature and principle that influence social capital .', 'Additionally , two new urban neighborhood design concept , cohousing and hybrid concept that adopt new form of social interaction , were studied , analyzed and then synthesized to suggest new neighborhood design concept , which is a heterotopia concept .', 'Finding : Heterotopia neighborhood concept aims to create real , different and heterogeneous functional space with different layer of meaning for people from different culture in one place .', 'Different visible enclosure are merged into space of otherness while the diversity gives a sense of entering another alternative place .', 'The heterotopias neighborhood design principles aim to create a wide variety of form , shape and element [ different new space for different ritual activity to reflect the otherness self-reflection ( homogeneous and scattered space ) ] and create linkage , hierarchy , contrast and mingling between space and place ; well-defined functional effective space ; different fantasy and leisure space ; high standard quality of life and otherness space ; flux in social realm and fluidity of space ; mixed use and joint experience ; and innovated technology space to offer strange new temporality .', 'Research limitations/implications : This research recommended that different community stakeholder should participate in planning process , neighborhood urban design and decision-making process about public space to strengthen the community tie and achieve a heterotopia concept .', 'Architect , urban designer and planner should adopt bottom-up design approach when designing neighborhood .', 'Additionally , to avoid poor social capital research study , the new researcher , practitioner and journal reviewer approaching social capital for the first time must read widely to gain an understanding of the concept from different perspective and narrow their scope to their particular area of interest .', 'Practical implication : This research highlights the need for empirical study to examine the relationships/interrelationships between all neighborhood design principle and social capital .', 'This might increase the knowledge on how we can design and increase the quality of neighborhood to foster social capital , which might offer interesting insight into how neighborhood urban design principle are combined to foster social capital within neighborhood context .', 'Originality/value : Neighborhood-based research encourages new suggesting concept in designing every single place in the residential neighborhood in a way that can adapt the new form of social interaction .', 'This research scanned the current concept of neighborhood design that concerned successfully with the changing form of social relationship to conclude some design feature and principle for neighborhood design to ensure and promote social public health and well-being .', 'This research offers a unique perspective for better understanding the relationship between the neighborhood urban design as a spatial dimension and social capital .', 'This research aims to enrich the socio-spatial knowledge and build a resilient urban community by suggesting theoretical urban neighborhood design concept , which is the heterotopia concept , and providing the urban designer and architect with a valuable thinking tool to design space .', 'Designing urban smart furniture for facilitating migrant ’ integration : The co-design workshop as approach for .', 'Wedding ceremony and cultural exchange in an Indian Ocean port city : The case of Zanzibar town .', 'This paper investigates the historical process in which wedding ritual were formed and 's housing development board housing .", 'Vernacular architecture is commonly believed to be a quaint representation of the history and tradition of a culture , built by average people using support this point of view are : 1 ) the ubiquity of the high rise and new town way of life ; 2 ) a shared value system and culture within the new town that is shaped by and reflected in the Le traitement de eaux usées ] .', 'This paper provides a brief discussion of the state of municipal wastewater treatment in France and Quebec .', 'It then presents some important change that have developed over the last ten year in the world and their potential influence on the future .', 'In France , 95 % of town of more than 10 000 resident have a wastewater treatment plant .', 'Construction of new plant reached 730 installation in 1976 , but has since declined to less than 300/year .', 'Among 11 310 site of more of 200 inhabitant , 5 % utilize only primary treatment and 50 % utilize the activated sludge process which represents 60 % of the treatment capacity .', 'In order to satisfy the European directive of May 21st 1991 , approximately 36 billion French Francs should be invested between 1994 and 2005 .', 'This investment represents new wastewater treatment facility for 17 million people .', "In Quebec , construction of wastewater treatment plant occurred mainly during the 80 's and 90 's .", 'Today , nearly 80 % of the population is served by wastewater treatment plant , which represent approximately 4,9 million resident .', 'This accounts for a flow rate of 5,3 million cubic meter per day .', 'Among 450 municipal treatment plant , those of the urban community of Montreal and Quebec represent nearly 60 % of the total wastewater treatment capacity of Quebec .', 'Physico-chemical treatment plant are the most significant ( 6 plant for 2,28 million resident ) followed by activated sludge process plant ( 40 plant for 0,69 million resident ) and plant using biofilter technology ( 9 plant for 0,75 million resident ) .', 'A total of approximately 320 small treatment plant , serving an average of 3 500 resident , use the aerated lagoon treatment .', 'Over the past decade technological development have resulted in an evolution that will modify the design and operation of wastewater treatment plant in the future : - the more widespread use of technique developed for the elimination of nitrogen and phosphorus ; - the realization of the importance of polluting charge transported by pluvial water ; the beginning of the resultant wastewater treatment plant adaptation ; - the limited development of anaerobic treatment that have survived the energy crisis ; - the valuable development of biological fixed-culture system for wastewater treatment and most notably , the biofilters ; - the appearance of promising membrane technology in wastewater treatment system , which could facilitate the definition of new treatment objective ; - the consideration of the global reliability of the wastewater treatment system instead of only peak performance ; - a more integrated vision for the prevention of pollution in industry ( clean technology ) as well as in the domestic environment ( integrated management of sewerage system and wastewater treatment plant ) .', 'Augmented reality system for tourism using image-based recognition .', 'This .', 'There is limited literature investigating the experience of urban park by older adult with disability .', 'This qualitative study , set in a region of New Zealand , explored the experience , public space ; examining the city 's history , culture , silhouette , local economic vitality , social interaction area as well as its contribution to the city is described and discussed .", 'Designed for threat : Surveillance , mass shooting , and pre-emptive design in school architecture .', 'Contemporary political discourse around security , immigration , and terrorist threat manifest in two trend in educational architectural : the fortress school and surveilled flow .', 'The fortress grows out of the urban-renewal movement of the post-World War II era , particularly on American university campus .', 'This architecture pre-empts threat by clamping down and fortifying its peripheral wall while controlling , surveilling , and limiting the number of entrance .', 'Lockdown procedure , encouraging surveillance among citizen , metal detector , increased police presence , and data-mining are all tactic at the fortress ’ disposal .', 'The alternative , much newer approach pre-empts threat by surveilling flow ; that is , inviting people inside the structure and encouraging traffic while relying on more remote and less obvious tactic for detecting undesirable , such as closed-circuit television ( CCTV ) , data-mining , and , like the fortress model , encouraging peer surveillance .', 'Surveilled flow maintains the gesture of openness ; however , this is mainly aesthetic , as other method of intrusive policing take place at less-visible level .', 'At the heart of both of these articulation of pre-emptive threat culture is the digital-age anxiety about the alignment and possible misalignment between visual and information-based citizen profile : Does the student or visitor appear to be a threat ?', 'Does his or her online behavior indicate potential threat ?', 'The profusion of information in the digital age meets this more primal desire to commensurate the appearance of risk with other form of information-based evidence of threat .', 'Digital-era concern about how to interpret a wealth of information at various institutional and cultural level pervade the riskscape in the developed world , and educational architecture is but one manifestation .', 'Mental map of the city : Element of visual argumentation and creativity in modern city planning [ Miesto mentalinis žemėlapis : Vizualinio argumentavimo elementai ir kūrybiškumas šiuolaikinio miesto planavimo procese ] .', 'Lewis Mumford in The City in History ( first edition in 1961 ) emphasises that the structure of modern city is partially responsible for many social problem seen in Western society .', 'Urban planning should concentrate on an organic relationship between people and their living space .', 'The city is a product of Earth , a fact of nature , man ’ s method of expression , Mumford writes in his The Culture of Cities ( first edition in 1938 ) .', 'This also means that both the designer and the user must have a high degree of creativity in order to design and utilise the built environment .', 'By analysing the definition of the city Mumford examines its change during history from ancient time to recent planning method .', 'He criticises the most dominant design process of the 20th century : the functionalist and mechanical urban design .', 'He is an advocate of the organic method in planning and understanding city .', 'The organic approach requires an active and creative approach as opposed to mere passive reception .', 'This organic approach by Mumford to understanding city is based on the theory of Kevin A. Lynch .', 'We may distinguish 3 normative way of city planning theory : ( 1 ) the cosmic , ( 2 ) the mechanic and ( 3 ) the organic model .', 'In my paper I will first apply the onion model of culture developed by Geert Hofstede for the city and its analysis , and also for the appearance of creativity in them .', 'After that I am going to examine the city with a special , architectural based mind map theory : the five element by Lynch .', 'Lynch suggests that these five element ( path , edge , district , node , landmark ) create the mental map for readability .', 'Finally , I will investigate a usage of mental map in modern city planning ( Le Corbusier ) and works on the process of “ debabelisation ” ( Otto Neurath ) .', 'Perceived effect of home renovation on independence of physically disabled Koreans living at home .', 'Purpose : This study aims to identify the potential effect of home renovation on independence promotion of physically disabled Koreans living at home .', 'Method : The method of the study is a survey with a questionnaire ; subject are physically disabled people living at home in rural and urban area in Korea .', 'The Functional Independence Measure was used to measure change in subject ’ level of independence .', 'Result : It was expected that if home were renovated according to individual need , disabled people ’ s independence level would be increased by one or more level compared to their current daily independence level in their existing home .', 'In particular , independence level concerning bathing and locomotion , which are low in existing condition , were expected to increase significantly with renovation .', 'Such effect on independence level were conspicuous for disabled people in rural area .', 'Conclusion : The result prove the positive effect of home renovation of disabled people ’ s independence , thus providing meaningful academic evidence on home renovation for disabled people .', 'Implication for rehabilitation Korea had a culture where support measures to aid the life independence of disabled person relied heavily on human service , leading to a lack of diversity in support measure .', 'By closing the gap between the resident ’ s disability and the inadequacy in their prevailing environment , house remodeling can be a crucial intervention for improving the independence of disabled person in their daily life .', 'Depending on the nature of their disability and their residential arrangement , disabled person have diverse need regarding home remodeling .', 'Implementing home remodeling in such a manner that suit the resident ’ s need is crucial to boosting their independence .', 'Because of this , remodeling personnel must interact with resident prior to the renovation while also strengthening their expertise .', 'The Development of a Web-Based Urban Soundscape Evaluation System .', 'Acoustic quality is one of the important aspect of urban design .', 'It is usually evaluated based on how loud the urban environment is .', "However , this approach does not consider people 's perception of the urban acoustic environment .", 'Therefore , a different method has been developed based on the perception of the acoustic environment using the concept of soundscape .', 'Soundscape is defined as the acoustic environment perceived by people who are part of the environment .', 'This approach considers the relationship between the sound source , the environment , and the people .', "The analysis of soundscape considers many aspect such as cultural aspect , people 's expectation , people 's experience of space , and social aspect .", 'Soundscape affects many aspect of human life such as culture , health , and the quality of life .', 'Urban soundscape management and planning must be integrated with the other aspect of urban design , both in the design and the improvement stage .', 'The soundscape concept seeks to make the acoustic environment as pleasant as possible in a space with or without uncomfortable sound source .', 'Soundscape planning includes the design of physical feature to achieve a positive perceptual outcome .', 'It is vital to gather data regarding the relationship between human and the component of a soundscape , e.g.', ', sound source , feature of the physical environment , the function of a space , and the expectation of the sound source .', 'The data can be measured and gathered using several soundscape evaluation method .', 'Soundscape evaluation is usually conducted using in-situ survey and laboratory experiment using a multi-speaker system .', 'Although these method have been validated and are widely used in soundscape analysis , there are some limitation in the application .', 'The in-situ survey needs to be done at one time with many people at the same time because it is hard to replicate the acoustic environment .', 'Conversely , the laboratory experiment does not have a problem with the repetition of the experiment .', 'This method requires a room with a multi-speaker reproduction system .', 'This project used a different method to analyse soundscape developed using headphone via the internet .', 'The internet system for data gathering has been established ; a website has enabled to reproduce high-quality audio and it has a system to design online questionnaire .', 'Furthermore , the development of a virtual reality system allows the reproduction of virtual audio-visual stimulus on a website .', 'Although the website has an established system to gather the required data , the problem is the validation of the reproduction system for soundscape analysis , which needs to be done with consideration of several factor : the suitable recording system , the effect of headphone variation , the calibration of the system , and the perception result from internet-based acoustic environment reproduction .', 'This study aims to develop and validate a web-based urban soundscape evaluation method .', 'By using this method , the experiment can be repeated easily and data can be gathered from many respondent .', 'Furthermore , the simplicity of the system allows for the application by the stakeholder in urban design .', 'The data gathered from this system is important for the design of an urban area with consideration of the acoustic aspect .', "'Auraldiversity ' : Defining a hearing- centred perspective to socially equitable design of the built environment .", 'Historically , sound , soundscape and human hearing have collectively received litt le att ention in the design of urban space and place , particularly with regard to the psychological and sociological impact of hearing on the experience of individual in the built environment .', "It is proposed that the sonic consideration which have been made in urban design are commonly developed within an assumption of otologically normal hearing , and , more broadly , without the acknowledgement of the actual diversity in people 's auditory and sensory ability .", "Existing consideration of sound and hearing within inclusive design research , particularly in the built environment , are grounded in an 'auraltypical ' perspective where the primary focus is hearing individual or those with hearing loss .", "This position supposes to some degree that an idealized otological profi le and consistent model of hearing profi ciency is shared amongst all citizen and engenders a culture of urban design driven by 'good/bad ' ear and homogenized sonic interaction .", "This paper introduces the theoretical paradigm of 'auraldiversity ' - an emerging agenda that acknowledges the diversity of human hearing and the multitude of element that place the hearing modality within a state of constant fl ux .", "The paper situates this theoretical perspective within the context of the built environment through the mapping of three 'auraldivergent ' hearing profi le .", 'Each profi le charts the lived sonic experience of a d/Deaf or disabled individual in the built environment .', 'The paper concludes by positioning the auraldiversity paradigm as a catalyst in the development of a hearing-centred approach to inclusive design research , a new agenda where the opportunity for more socially and sonically equitable design of the built environment is established .', 'Towards a sustainable crowdsourced sound heritage archive by public participation : The soundsslike project .', 'This paper explains how user-centered design approach shapes a cultural heritage project in the sustainability context .', 'The project aims to protect urban sound as intangible cultural heritage element and turn the action of protecting sound into a collaborative work .', 'Sound are of great significance in daily urban life and in culture as they carry emotion and awaken cultural memory .', 'Thus , they deserve to be protected and transferred to next generation .', 'In this paper , we first evaluate soundscapes as an intangible cultural heritage element , second we explore the presentation technique in soundscape study in the literature , then we explain how the method implemented step by step , and finally we introduce the two outcome : The library archive ( The Soundscape of Istanbul project ) and the crowdsourced web archive ( The Soundsslike project ) .', 'The Soundscape of Istanbul project aims to collect and archive cultural and urban sound of the city while The Soundsslike project is basically a crowdsourced online sound archive which invites people to record symbolic urban sound and upload them to the online sound archive .', 'This online platform was built and displayed in an exhibition by mean of an interactive tabletop interface to learn more from user and contributor , and to enrich the archive content by raising public awareness of urban sound .', "Lewis Mumford 's Urbanism and the Problem of Environmental Modernity .", 'This essay reconsiders the early career of Lewis Mumford and the assumption that modernity has been disastrous environmentally .', 'Might it be possible to see Mumford , especially in his writing of the 1930s , as an early exemplar of green urbanism ?', 'Within environmental history , Mumford has been treated mostly as a regionalist - sometimes even as an opponent of the city .', "This essay argues that in fact his path toward ecological `` balance '' led directly through the city , not out of it .", "Indeed , he gives us access to modernity 's ambivalence and complexity by accompanying his trenchant critique of modern city with a positive vision for how people might design and occupy urban space more sustainably .", "To rediscover Mumford is to reconsider the city not just as a site of erasure and hubristic `` renewal '' but also as a landscape full of what he called `` remnant '' and `` persistents '' ; it is to rediscover modernity 's environmental possibility , in line with current trend in urban ecology and design , and with the new momentum in urban environmental history to combine material and cultural perspective .", 'Environmental restoration and design for recreation and ecotourism .', 'A wetland center in London , park in downtown San Francisco , a wildlife sanctuary in Arcata , and a wetland park on the outskirt of Las Vegas-what do these urban and suburban location have in common ?', 'They are leading example of a new restoration design approach that is squarely placed at the interface of nature and culture .', 'This multidisciplinary paradigm bridges the gap between an ecological approach preoccupied with returning damaged landscape to an imagined original state and a landscape design approach concerned with creating a place for people to reinhabit .', 'Environmental Restoration and Design for Recreation and Ecotourism is the first book to provide a detailed examination of the entire process of restoring damaged or abandoned landscape to benefit both nature and people , specifically for the purpose of recreation and ecotourism .', 'With a focus on history , planning , methodology , design , and construction , it explores five case study of successful regenerative landscape design project and gives reader an inside look at the evolution of design project .', 'Two of the case offer a particularly comprehensive review of award-winning project : the reparation of the degraded Las Vegas Wash into Clark County Wetlands Park and the transformation of the abandoned Barn Elms Reservoirs into the London Wetland Centre .', 'Supported by extensive photographs , table , map , sketch , and schematic , these case study trace how idea are first conceived and then adopted , transformed , or even abandoned along the way .', 'Each case study also includes a questions-and-answers discussion with designer and manager .', 'Emphasizing the need for interdisciplinary cooperation , the book presents lesson learned from some of the most innovative project in regenerative landscape design .', 'Old wall , modern city : research on urban memory of disappearing ancient Beijing city wall .', 'Purpose – Ancient city wall are typical linear space element of Beijing that represent the transformation of urban form over the past 800 year and have greatly influenced the memory of the entire city .', 'However , recently , most of the wall have been torn down in the process of fast urbanization and old city renewal .', 'The purpose of this paper is to focus on people ’ s cognition and evaluation of urban memory during this pull-down-and-preserve process .', 'Design/methodology/approach – A sample of 380 participant was investigated on a number of issue using questionnaire , including memory case reminder ( stability , variability , temporality ) , emotional bonding with memory case ( identity , dependence , authenticity ) , and socio-demographic variable ( age , education , life experience , length of residence ) .', 'The urban memory cognition model and attitude evaluation value model which were based on Likert scale were used to process the collected data .', 'Finding – In the three aspect of memory case reminder , stability and temporary element can be most cognized , whereas variability element are more difficult due to their change over time .', 'As for emotional bonding with memory case , people show a high level of identification with the wall ; the wall ’ memory being passed down could enhance people ’ s memory when mentioning Beijing .', 'Further , higher education group consider the wall ’ authenticity to be most important and are unwilling to accept the outcome of walls-ruins park ; older adult have tolerant attitude to the ruin park .', 'Originality/value – This study could not only contribute to the excavation of urban memory , but also strengthen citizen ’ sense of identity and cohesiveness , thus shaping the spirit and culture of the city .', 'Some finding could provide applicable guideline for urban heritage protection and contribute a new perspective on the interrelationship between people and their physical surroundings .', 'Mapping the intangible cultural heritage of ethnic community : Designing an interactive cultural history of Koreatown .', "This paper presents the interactive online cultural history 'The Seoul of Los Angeles : Contested Identity and Transnationalism in Immigrant Space ' ( http : //seoulofla.com/ ) .", 'Informed by interaction design and urban study , this project examines and visualizes the sociocultural network shaping immigrant community and how local neighborhood negotiate a sense of place within an increasingly globalized space .', 'Geographer Doreen Massey recognizes space not as a static entity but as the product of interrelation from the immensity of the global to the intimately tiny .', 'These interrelation are part of a story , an interpreted history that change and develops over time .', 'One could recognize cultural heritage in a similar way-as dynamic and part of a narrative trajectory that is not merely frozen in a romanticized or essentialist past .', 'Much of what constitutes the dynamic of ethnic community formation is intangible as it is largely a lived experience rather than one that is necessarily documented or archived .', 'As such , this project serves as a digital archive and platform for community storytelling that enriches our understanding of the city and the often intangible narrative that create a sense of place .', 'Currently , Los Angeles has the largest population of Koreans in the United States living outside of Korea .', "Nicknamed the ' L.A .", "district of Seoul City ' , most visitor understand Koreatown as an extension of Seoul .", 'But , what most people may not know is that the majority of inhabitant who comprise its residential and working class population are not Korean , but Latino .', 'The everyday space of this community is inhabited by a mix of immigrant coming from Mexico , Central and South America , and other part of Asia including Bangladesh .', 'These network of nationalisms converge in the urban space of Koreatown .', 'This contests predominant conception of ethnic enclave being understood as homogenous and makes us re-imagine what we think we understand about them-they are increasingly becoming polycentric in complex way .', 'Combining design , documentary and issue in contemporary medium study including global/local relation , ethnic and urban study , this work uses new medium and mapping to create greater awareness of our built environment and the people who populate it .', 'Mapping is a dynamic system that changes according to the shift in culture and community that characterize any geographic place .', 'How can this system be visualized in order to read a space with newly informed imagination ?', 'What kind of urban interface could be designed to communicate with the space we move through and what overlooked story could be uncovered in order to enrich our understanding of city and the intangible cultural history embedded in them ?', 'Such question are explored in this project .', 'Dynamic of eco-cities : A review of concept towards operationalizing sustainable urbanization .', 'The need for city to transition towards a more sustainable urban development has become imperative given the combined impact of climate change , global ecological overshoot , and rapid urbanization .', 'The Eco-city has emerged as an urban modernization concept that attempts to reframe urban development for sustainable outcome , yet there have been several alteration and coining of new terminology to describe an eco-city , mainly based of concept and the design methodology and/or the purpose the city is to serve .', 'Even though the eco-city concept and development profess to have some basic principle - dogma - mostly based on urban sustainability , the rapid change in terminology in recent time calls the attention of many policy maker , investor , development promoter and stakeholder , as well as researcher alike .', 'Beyond these corporate border , are also the culture ( people ) and the environment that are influenced by ( and interacts with ) the eco-city .', 'However , there is no widely accepted framework for assessing Eco-cities .', 'Besides , the method and outcome of Eco-cities ; and how these outcome can be evaluated to determine the performance of Eco-cites remain unresolved .', 'This paper presents a framework for assessing the performance of Eco-cities .', 'It argues that due to the inherent difference in the culture , topography , climate , economy , infrastructural base , and technological advancement etc .', 'of city around the world , Eco-cities may embody distinct characteristic in the way they are understood and applied in different region .', 'Nonetheless , using a common benchmark across geographical region , one can do performance assessment of Eco-cities , which can be basis for replication , accessibility , as well as serve as goal metric .', '“ Welcome to The Shop ” : Insight and reflection from teaching hip-hop-based spoken word poetry for social justice .', 'Purpose : The purpose of this paper is to describe the way in which hip-hop pedagogy and literacy encouraged middle school student to explore performance poetry as a tool to “ ( w ) right ” the truth ( s ) about learning and living in their local and global community .', 'Design/methodology/approach : Collaborative self-study research methodology were used by the author , a black male teacher educator and hip-hop cultural insider , along with two white , female reading specialist and hip-hop cultural outsider , to collect and analyze the practice and behavior used in The Shop – an after-school hip-hop-based spoken word poetry club for middle school student in a small , urban public school district in Northeastern USA .', 'Finding : Three primary finding emerge : teacher with limited cultural and content knowledge of hip-hop may struggle to negotiate real and perceived curricular constraint associated with using pedagogy with hip-hop text and aesthetic in traditional school contexts , the intersection of teacher ’ racial , cultural and gender identity informed the respective practice and behavior in a number of interesting way , and using hip-hop pedagogy for social justice in public school requires a delicate balance of both transparency and discretion on the part of teacher .', 'Originality/value : Study finding are salient for in- and pre-service English teacher and English educator , as they offer insight and reflection on the instructional and relational challenge cultural outsider may face when using hip-hop culture to create space and opportunity for young people to talk back and speak truth to power .', 'A case study : Learning garden in an urban indigenous community : Expanding the scope of learning .', 'Garden and learning in garden are increasingly a focus in education , restoration , and community development .', 'In this chapter I consider garden and the opportunity for learning they afford from an expansive view of culture , learning and socio-historical practice .', 'At their core , garden are broadly about the cultivation of plant and land , however , gardening reflects complex variation , goal , and value affording various form of identity and meaning .', 'Indeed throughout history human community have cultivated and harvested plant for food , for medicine , for aesthetic , for material resource , and much more .', 'The specific of these practice have evolved and shifted over time and varied across cultural community , however , regardless of their specific form gardening practice are foundational reflective of the relation between human and the natural world .', 'The rise of learning garden is perhaps a resilient response and remembering given the erosion of people from land that has emerged in the technologically saturated twentieth century .', 'Given this expanded view of garden in human community and the present socio-historical dynamic , what might the possibility for learning garden be ?', 'What opportunities for learning do learning garden afford ?', 'What are the variation in learning garden ?', 'How do the particular of garden ( their design , their goal , the plant grown , the program and practice associated with them ) impact learning ?', 'Largely , the answer to these question are unknown or under-explored .', 'Swettenham pier waterfront redevelopment , Penang .', 'A waterfront is a place where life of a city bloomed .', 'Water is the source of life .', 'Life is the practice of living .', "A waterfront signified a city 's growth , bounded by water .", "Swettenham Pier is one part of Penang Island 's east coast waterfront link , and happened to be at the sport where Georgetown started .", 'The spot where in history , Sir Francis Light landed on this island and where Georgetown is established along with the blooming of international entrepot activity .', "It was glorious back in the late 80 's .", 'The main objective of this thesis is to bring back the glory moment of Swettenham Pier , giving back the waterfront to the people of Georgetown , people of Penang .', 'Having to attend to this said aim , the redevelopment of Swettenham Pier waterfront is to give a chance to the people to claim a part of this waterfront , for living , for leisure or for any unplanned activity , as to establish its aim to contribute back to the local people , local culture and local living .', 'This call for a strategy to design a waterfront to revive the history , while injecting new life to the place for people and activity to be carry on care freely .', 'The design potential of this project is to look through the entire master plan of the waterfront and then move into the micro elements that support the entire scheme .', 'The master plan plays a crucial role in supporting the waterfront with various type of activity that serve various demographic of user .', 'The redevelopment of the new cruise terminal would also be explored thoroughly in conjunction with Penang Structure Plan in order to come out with the design that could cope with future development .', 'One of the key outcome of this research is that community magnet or a civic component inserted in the scheme will contribute back to the local people and culture .', 'Cultural and linguistic localization of game to bridge the digital and cultural divide in indigenous population .', 'Localization of technology is now widely applied to the preservation and revival of the culture of indigenous people around the world , most commonly through the translation into indigenous language , which has been proven to increase the adoption of technology .', 'However , this current form of localization excludes two demographic group , which are key to the effectiveness of localization effort in the African context : the younger generation ( under the age of thirty ) with an Anglo- American cultural view who have no need or interest in their indigenous culture ; and the older generation ( over the age of fifty ) who are very knowledgeable about their indigenous culture , but have little or no knowledge on the use of a computer .', 'This paper presents the design of a computer game engine that can be used to provide an interface for both technology and indigenous culture learning for both generation .', 'Four indigenous Ugandan game are analyzed and identified for their attractiveness to both generation , to both rural and urban population , and for their propensity to develop IT skills in older generation .', 'Ecotourism : Sustainable indigenous policy and its effect in Mayan community , Southern Mexico .', 'In a sustainable development paradigm , the promotion of alternative tourism seeks simultaneously : preservation of nature , alleviation of poverty and consideration to ancestral culture .', 'Nevertheless , in an analysis of multilateral and federal policy with methodological triangulation of survey , in-depth interview and participative observation , about the tourism market ’ s dynamic in the ecotouristic Mayan community of Lacanjá Chansayab Chiapas , it was found that the aim of alternative tourism have not been achieved because the change from a primary to a tertiary economic sector of indigenous ’ livelihood has induced : 1 ) inter-ethnic struggle over economic natural resource management ; 2 ) upward and downward spiral marginalization ; 3 ) creation of urban environmental problem ; 4 ) ancestral culture have reconfigured their social function ; 5 ) natural and cultural capital have become global stock , less favoring indigenous people .', 'The cause are , on the one hand , the intervention of multi-sectorial policy in Mexico is diffuse and without local participation in their design .', 'On the other hand , the absence of impact assessment ex-ante to government intervention .', 'Pafos cultural capital of Europe 2017 : Landscape intervention in the Urban fabric as a tourist development tool .', 'The relationship between tourism and site of cultural and natural significance exists since the time of Greek Antiquity and strongly encourages landscape restoration of urban site .', 'This paper provides an up-to-date overview of the relationship between cultural landscape heritage and tourism , describes strategy that can lead to sustainable tourism where cultural heritage is a key factor , and formulates a methodology for landscape intervention , with a particular focus on the dynamic of landscape transformation and the rigorous reading of the ecological and cultural dimension of the landscape of the town of Pafos , European Capital of Culture for 2017 , as a major mean to generate economic benefit from recreation and tourism .', 'Pafos is a town with monument of unique value from every period of its rich cultural tradition where ancient amphitheater , agora , and archeological site co-exist in harmony with the unique Mediterranean seashore and the sensitive natural ecosystem of the Akamas peninsula .', 'Pafos as European Capital of Culture for 2017 aim at developing a strategic sustainable plan to reinvent the town as a cultural landscape used as a tourist development tool .', 'It will implement an extensive urban landscape design intervention plan , with the aim of restoring open public space , creating link between important site and archaeological space , and recovering the lost connection with the natural environment , the land and the sea based on aspect of sustainable and eco-friendly tourism development .', 'Such a landscape approach tempts to integrate natural and cultural heritage by recognizing that the current landscape is the product of long-term and complex interrelationship between people and the environment .', "This research may also serve as a basis for future strategic landscape intervention in the urban fabric as a tourism policy and cultural heritage planning establishing an exclusive linkage to the `` sense of place '' and landscape design .", 'Cultural route , trail and the experience of place .', 'This chapter explores the growing field of self-guided route and trail within the context of the visitor experience and considers the extent to which these popular cultural tourism product reflect contemporary thinking on visitor ’ engagement with tourism offering .', 'Self-guided route and trail are found in both urban and rural contexts and provide an interpreted , themed journey which can be travelled on foot , by bicycle , horseback , car , or in some case even followed underwater .', 'Trail can vary in scale from the very local , forexample a town trail , to the international , exemplified by the Council of Europe Cultural Routes project which has developed a number of long-distance , cross-border route interpreting pan-European theme .', 'Timothy and Boyd ( 2003 : 51 ) have categorised trail as linear visitor attraction that can be mega ( international ) , large ( national and regional ) , or small ( local ) , and note that the mega and large-scale trail are predominantly rural whilst smaller trail are almost always urban based .', 'The idea of travelling along a pre-determined route is not a new one .', 'Indeed , trail may have been amongst the earliest artefact produced by human as a means of understanding their world as they found their way through it .', 'Historically , the act of moving through the environment created cognitive connection and knowledge of place as well as producing a physical pathway ( Turnbull 2007 : 142 ) , and these remain important aspect of trail today .', 'Trail have a rich symbolism as many culture have origin myth where the creator passes through empty space , according it meaning as they travel ( Snead 2009 ) .', 'The path is often representative of the journey through life itself as exemplified in literature from John Bunyan ’ s The Pilgrim ’ s Progress ( 1678 ) , to Jack Kerouac ’ s On the Road ( 1957 ) .', 'In cultural term , the trail is often characterised as liminal space , full of possibility and used as a setting for chance meeting or farewell in novel , poem and film ( Snead 2009 ) .', 'In the contemporary tourism destination , trail are developed to interpret a variety of story ranging from local history ( San Francisco ’ s Gold Rush Trail , USA ) , industry ( Ruhr Industrial Heritage Trail , Germany ) , food and wine ( South African Wine Trail ) , to famous people ( the Mozart Route ) and historical event ( the Pendle Witch Trail in Lancashire , UK ) .', 'Trail are usually developed in partnership , with local authority taking the lead in trail development in the UK ( Hayes and MacLeod 2008 ) .', 'The range of stakeholder involved typically includes tourism organisation , visitor attraction , civic society , local history group and business who will benefit from the additional visitor footfall .', 'By their nature , trails form business cluster that should encourage interaction and community participation and this potential has recently been investigated by the Council of Europe in their report on the impact of European Cultural route on small and medium-sized enterprise ( SMEs ) ( Council of Europe 2011 ) .', 'Trail have proved to be highly flexible in both the theme that they interpret and in the purpose to which they are put .', 'In recent year , trail have been developed for conservation purpose , routing visitor away from sensitive site , providing information on environmental issue and encouraging the use of public transport .', 'Their potential as tool for economic development has been recognised ( Strauss and Lord 2001 ; Bowker et al .', '2007 ) and they can provide opportunity for the wider use of local facility by visitor , enhancing their engagement with place .', 'As al-Hagla ( 2010 : 2 ) state , ‘ a heritage trail is one physical manifestation of the interaction between tourist , local , and the host place ’ .', 'Clearly visitor management and educational rationale are signi ?', 'cant and the physical benefit of walking or cycling are promoted through trail use , with some trail having been speci ?', 'cally developed to address health issue ( Geiger and Werner 2009 ) .', 'Trail are therefore seen to be a useful mean of satisfying a range of objective , often at very little cost as many trail consist simply of an interpretive leaflet showing a map with point of interest indicated .', 'Other , more complex trail utilise interpretation panel , sign-posts and marker to guide the visitor .', 'Increasingly , trails information is made available online with dedicated trail website and interactive map becoming more common ( for example Scotland ’ s Malt Whisky Trail on www.maltwhiskytrail.com ) .', 'Trail developer usetrails as a tool for visitor management whilst providing an interesting route to follow .', 'In developing trail , specific theme are chosen and site selected in order to tell a particular story .', 'The deliberate theming of place though construct such as trail has come under scrutiny , from Relph ( 1976 ) and his ‘ museumisation ’ of space , to more contemporary author who comment on the cultural significance of such themed space ( e.g .', 'Lukas 2007 ; Urry and Larsen 2011 ) .', 'Relph ’ s critique of the museumisation of space centre around the imposition of the museum idiom of authority , selectivity and interpretation on public space and the trail ’ s role of highlighting specific site rejecting a chosen theme can certainly be seen as a contributing factor in this transformation of space , turning real place into trivial and inauthentic area .', 'Lukas ( 2007 : 2 ) comment on the ‘ immutable and unifying nature that characterises a theme ’ , suggesting that once a space has been themed , it is difficult to encourage visitor to see it in any other way .', 'When consideringthe borrowed and reworked symbol and meaning that themed space utilise in their exploration of the tourist gaze , Urry and Larsen ( 2011 ) note that these themed ‘ country ’ present appealing aspect of place which may not necessarily relate to actual historical or geographical reality and which may obscure dissonant or contested heritage .', 'Indeed , trail can be seen as the ultimate expression of the tourist gaze as they are designed around visual sign and the route is literally a set of instruction to look at speci ?', 'c monument , building or vista .', 'The point of interest on a trail are ‘ … usually …those element that can appeal to the visual sense and can help tell a story that is mostly structured around a clear chronological logic ’ ( Markwell et al .', '2004 : 460 ) .', 'The trail directs the visitor ’ s gaze away from that which is irrelevant or merely unsightly , thus promoting a highly structured mode of seeing that is said to be characteristic of the tourist ’ s experience .', 'Of course visitor will always ignore instruction , sabotage arrangement and subvert the hegemonic message of a themed route , and indeed some trail have been designed to encourage visitor to dip in and out of the story and compare heritage theme with contemporary culture on the street ( Shaw and MacLeod 2000 ) .', 'This tendency of tourist towards creativity and subversion has been reflected in the recent ‘ performance turn ’ in critical study of tourism which emphasises the active experience of tourism ( Edensor 2000 ) and a multi-sensory ‘ embodied gaze ’ ( Urry and Larsen 2011 ) .', 'This ‘ performance turn ’ suggests that tourist are no longer simply spectator of an organised scene but wish to be actively engaged , experiencing place sensually .', 'This new way of thinking about tourist practice allows us to reconsider the role and potential of the trail as , ‘ in contrast to study portraying tourism as an over-determined stage where tourist passively follow prescripted route and script , the performance turn also uncovers creativity , detour and productive practice ’ ( Urry and Larsen 2011 : 192–93 ) .', 'To a certain extent , the trail has already been seen to have embraced aspect of the performance turn in encouraging a more embodied gaze through the increasing use of sound .', 'Audio guide have long been used in museum and gallery but new digital technology has allowed the development of downloadable audio trail and mobile application ( ‘ apps ’ ) to be used flexibly in the field .', 'These audio trail can be followed en route using ipod , MP3 player and mobile phone , and are described as being ‘ more nuanced , embodied , complex , multi sensory method of experiencing and representing our surroundings ’ ( Butler 2007 : 15 ) .', 'Typically they use music , recorded interview and performance to create a soundscape to be listened to whilst following a map-based trail .', 'An audio trail developed in Wapping in East London , for example , uses the tale of an elderly woman remembering a lost love as the basis for the walk through the area .', 'Community group were involved in the creation of the walk , which uses speech and sound effect to create a performance in which the user fully participates ( Ball et al .', '2005 ) .', 'The performance turn in tourism study can also be considered within the wider context of Pine and Gilmore ’ s ( 1999 , 2011 ) influential work on the experience economy , which suggests that contemporary consumer have moved beyond the mere consumption of product and service and are increasingly seeking unique and engaging experience .', 'The author apply this new experience economy to all service provider but the concept is perhaps particularly apt in relation to the tourism and hospitality sector where , for example , the Disney Corporation has been providing successful model of themed experience since the 1950s ( Bryman 1995 ) .', 'Several author have specifically applied Pine and Gilmore ’ s idea to the tourism sector ( Richards 2001 ; Oh et al .', '2007 ; Ek et al .', '2008 ) , recognising that the tourism industry has had a pioneering role in the staging of experience , andVisit Britain reported in 2010 that holiday will become more experiential in the future , concentrating on ‘ immersion ’ in experience rather than the destination itself ( Visit Britain 2010 ) .', 'Pine and Gilmore ( 1999 ) claim that experiences fall into four distinctive realm – the entertain-ment , education , aesthetic and escapist realm .', 'Experience are further characterised according to whether they require active or passive participation and whether they result in the absorption or immersion of the participant .', 'Pine and Gilmore suggest that the most compelling experience are those that encompass all four realm in the ‘ sweet spot ’ or ‘ optimal tourist experience ’ , as Oh et al .', '( 2007 : 121 ) define it .', 'In order to assist provider in designing experience that hit this ‘ sweet spot ’ , the author propose four principle : provide a compelling theme ; use positive cue to afirm the nature of the experience ; provide memorabilia as a physical reminder of the encounter ; and ?', 'nally , utilise all four sens to fully enrol and engage participant ( Pine and Gilmore 1999 ; Pine and Gilmore 2011 ) .', 'As tool for encouraging more engagement with place , trail may benefit from a more experiential approach to their design , as explored in the case study ( Box 46.1 ) .', 'Although the research presented in the case study did find example of good practice in the production of engaging and creative trail , the finding suggest that trail are still being viewed as product rather than experience by their developer .', 'It would appear that more could be done to realise the potential of English town trail ( and by extension , all route and trail ) to provide more interesting and interactive ‘ optimal tourist experience ’ ( Oh et al .', '2007 ) .', 'Feature of a local culture as viewed from the perspective of stranger .', 'This article describes a unique mixing of grounded theory methodology ( GTM ) and autoethnographic method in a study of the difficulty faced by individual ( of the professional class ) moving from the cosmopolitan urban area of Mexico to a middle-sized , more traditional city , as I had done when I moved from Mexico City to Aguacalientes .', 'The problem of suddenly finding myself to be a stranger in my own land began as a personal concern , but migrated into a professional sociological concern as I designed a GTM study that would allow me to examine the issue from a wider perspective.For this study , I conducted 19 two-to-three hour interview of individual who fit the criterion of professional migrant .', 'The transcript were analyzed in the computer program MAXQDA .', 'Analysis included reviewing the interview transcripts multiple time , coding them , writing memo , and sketching diagram that would describe my emerging notion .', 'While autoethnography was a starting point for my work , GTM was central to the research design and analysis technique I followed.This investigation revealed that smaller city in Mexico , a rapidly developing nation , are experiencing a broad range of social pressure at many level of society .', 'These pressure result in sharp dichotomy that are experienced among insider and outsider .', 'Thus , in Aguascalientes , insider , on the one hand , present themselves to outsider as hermetic , double-sided , mediocre , incompetent , and , on the other hand , they also present themselves as kind , open , good people , having a strong civic education .', 'These strong contrast in how insider and outsider view each other seem to be an expression of wider change in which individual find themselves in the modern Mexican context .', 'Participatory design in rural environment .', 'Rural environment is the reflect of the historical practice over the time , mutually feedback of human settle , activity , nature .', 'Design without community participation and unnecessary change in settlement pattern , intensity disorder in rural environment and cultural landscape .', 'This situation emphasizes the need of new
