their life challenges more efficiently and increases the likelihood of return to a normal life .', "Social support plays a different role in homeless woman 's life , as gender culture often causes them to be exposed to more risk .", "The purpose of this paper is to identify homeless people 's access to social support from their network member , with a comparison between men and woman .", 'Design/methodology/approach - In this study , a survey method was used with an administrated questionnaire .', 'Participant were recruited from among the homeless people ( men and woman ) who used the municipal social service in shelter and social service center in Tehran .', 'The main variable in this study included frequency of contact , social support , and gender .', 'Finding - The result have shown significant difference between homeless men and homeless woman in term of frequency of contact and receipt of social support .', 'Homeless woman contacted their network member more often than did homeless men and also received more support .', "There seems to be a strong correlation between the receipt of social support and woman 's greater ability for social communication , as well as with traditional culture , which considers woman to be weak and dependent so that they receive more support compared with men .", 'The weakness of social support , especially among homeless men , requires serious attention ; however , homeless woman are not in a favorable situation either .', 'Originality/value - The social network of homeless people who usually live on the street and in public place without permanent shelter are weak because of various reason , including poverty , addiction , immigration , and divorce .', 'The weakness of social support leads to an escalation of their vulnerability .', 'Thus , it is necessary , in social policy and service , to improve the social network of high-risk people such as homeless people , which would help the rehabilitation process and reduce the probability of exposure to harm .', 'Change in blood pressure among user of lay health worker or volunteer operated community-based blood pressure program over time : a systematic review protocol .', "REVIEW QUESTION/OBJECTIVE : The objective of this review is to identify study reporting on lay health worker- or volunteer-led community-based program for blood pressure screening and cardiovascular awareness in order to determine if these program contribute to change in blood pressure among participant over time.The specific question for this review is : What are the change in blood pressure among adult user of community-based blood pressure screening and awareness program operated by lay health worker or volunteer as measured by the difference in systolic and diastolic blood pressure between the user 's first visit to the program and their last visit to the program ?", 'BACKGROUND : Cardiovascular disease , such as stroke and heart disease , are quickly becoming global disease manifesting in country and community where they traditionally had not been widespread .', "The World Health Organization ( WHO ) has reported that `` in the Asia/Pacific region , [ cardiovascular disease ] has become increasingly prevalent in recent decade , and now account for about one third of all death '' .", 'One risk factor that can lead to cardiovascular disease is hypertension .', 'Based on WHO data from 2008 , hypertension is now a global problem affecting 27 % of the population 25 year of age or older.The risk for cardiovascular disease also appears to be higher among people in urban area .', "A recent United Nations population report indicates that in the next 40 year we could see an increase in the world 's population by 2.3 billion people .", 'The majority of these people will be residing in urban area , particularly in developing nation .', "Between 2011 and 2050 , `` the population living in urban area is projected to gain 2.6 billion , passing from 3.6 billion in 2011 to 6.3 billion in 2050 '' .", "Population growth in urban area is therefore not only projected to include the expected population growth but also expected to include a shift of rural population to urban center and `` most of the population growth expected in urban area will be concentrated in the city and town of the less developed region '' .", 'This growth of urban area has the potential to put enormous pressure on health care system that are already struggling to cope with the rapid increase in disease thought to be more prevalent in Western society , such as cardiovascular diseases.Hypertension may be difficult to treat due to a number of factor .', 'Globally , access to antihypertensive medication , hypertension screening , and access to medical care vary from one country to another .', 'Lifestyle factor , such as salt and alcohol consumption , stress , smoking , body weight , and exercise , are risk factor for hypertension that may be influenced by culture , which can in turn support or hinder lifestyle decision that could significantly affect blood pressure .', 'Hypertension , however , is easy to detect .', 'A trained person with access to a low-cost sphygmomanometer can detect abnormal blood pressure quickly ; however , access to trained personnel is not universally guaranteed .', 'Globally - according to one model of skilled health care worker density and total requirement offered for discussion by the Global Health Workforce Alliance and WHO - there could currently be an estimated shortage of over seven million skilled health care worker ( midwifes , nurse and physician ) , as measured against a theoretical density of skilled health care worker to population .', 'The shortage of skilled health care worker in this model could grow to over 12 million by 2035 if the assumption of the model and population growth estimate are valid .', 'Through rapid urbanization the potential for inequity in access to healthcare is also increased.Over the last few year , a number of community-based blood pressure screening and education initiative have been established .', 'These initiative have been created either as part of research , as part of community outreach program by publicly funded agency , or as part of an outreach by not-for-profit organization with a particular interest in reducing cardiovascular disease in specific hard-to-reach population .', 'Several systematic review have been conducted to assess different model for delivering service to people living with high blood pressure to assess community-based program with a focus on cardiovascular disease , and to assess effectiveness of community health worker ( CHW ) in a variety of setting .', 'These systematic review point to the importance of distinguishing between different category of health care provider , their training and their role in program delivery when assessing study for possible inclusion in a systematic review.In a systematic review of study from the US by Brownstein et al .', 'focusing on the effectiveness of community health worker ( CHWs ) in the care of people with hypertension , this category of health care provider went under many different name .', "Community health worker in this review were defined as `` any health worker who carried out function related to health care deliver , were trained as part of an intervention , had no formal paraprofessional or professional designation , and had a relationship with the community being served '' .", 'One of the finding from this review was the wide variety of formal training of the CHWs .', 'In other part of the world , a CHW might be defined differently .', "In their review of CHW-based program focusing on child 's health , Bhattacharyya , Winch , LeBan and Tien found that `` in general CHWs are not paid salary because the MOH ( Ministry of Health ) or donor do not consider salary to be sustainable .", 'Yet CHWs are often held accountable and supervised as if they were employee .', 'Community health worker program must recognize that CHWs are volunteer ( emphasis in original ) , even if they receive small monetary or nonmonetary incentive .', "They are volunteering their time to serve the community '' .", 'One Canadian model for delivering a cardiovascular awareness program designed to reach older adult through their primary care provider is based on volunteer with basic training to perform blood pressure measurement and cardiovascular health information.In a global review of a wide range of public health and health promotion initiative operated by lay health worker from 2005 , Lewin et al .', 'identified over 40 different name or term for a lay health worker .', 'However , the definition of a lay health worker used by Lewin et al .', 'is very similar to the definition of CHWs offered by Brownstein et al .', 'Lewin et al .', "'s systematic review was the only study with a global focus that was located that reviewed study of program with a cardiovascular component using lay health worker .", 'In this study , the sample size of study focusing on lay health worker and cardiovascular disease was small ( N=3 ) and the result from two of the study were inconclusive to the point where the author felt they could not pool the results.While a lay health worker may or may not receive some compensation for their work , volunteer in higher income area of the world such as in North America typically do not receive any compensation .', 'Volunteer , as observed by Bhattacharyya et al.', ', are common in many part of the world , and in some area they provide delivery of program and service that reach hundred of thousand of individual .', 'One challenge for this systematic review will therefore be to isolate those program that are delivered by lay health worker or volunteer who receive little or no compensation and program where staff is paid .', 'The importance of this distinction is on one hand related to cost - as observed by Bhattacharyya et al.', ', many organization responsible for delivery of community-based program do not have funding for salaried staff .', 'On the other hand there might be other factor in the relationship between a community being served by a program and the staff delivering the program .', 'One such factor could be linked to the role of the person delivering the program as either a paid health care professional or an unpaid lay health worker or volunteer.Through this proposed JBI systematic review , the reviewer will focus on community-based blood pressure screening and health information program delivered by either lay health worker or volunteer .', 'Previous systematic review have indicated that program focusing on blood pressure reduction delivered in a variety of setting and delivered by a variety of health care professional might lower blood pressure among program participant over time .', 'This systematic review will be limited to community-based program rather than hospital or research facility-based program , and to program delivered by lay health worker or volunteer rather than program delivered by paid community health worker , nurse or team of health care provider under direction of a primary care provider .', 'Compared to other recent systematic review which focused on study with comparison group and included few study where lay health worker were involved , this systematic review will attempt to fill this gap in knowledge about program delivered by lay health worker or volunteer by focusing on non-randomized controlled study which report blood pressure change over time in program targeting the general population .', 'Community-based program might have a variety of design with a number of different intervention , and where possible these design and intervention will be identified and subgroup analysis conducted as appropriate .', 'It is hoped that this systematic review can extend the work by Lewin et al .', 'by identifying additional study globally , focusing on program delivered by lay health worker or volunteer but limited to study reporting change in blood pressure over time .', 'Where possible , a meta-analysis of the change in blood pressure over time among participant in these program will be conducted .', '( ABSTRACT TRUNCATED )', 'HIV and the Lesotho Highlands Water socio cultural reality : 1 ) Scientific medicine , based on Hippocrates , cultivated and practiced in the higher strata of urban life ; it corresponds to contemporary culture , of Greco Latin root , brought by the Spaniards and developed by the cultural contribution from 'civilized ' people : it appears as the foundation of the organization and progress of the country as a nation .", '2 ) Indigenous medicine of the sierra appearing as the survival of medicine of ancient Peru .', 'It is the correlation of the pre Hispanic thought and social organization since the primitive time and transculturation .', 'Young People ’ s View on Dating Violence Prevention in an Urban Turkish Context : Developing Effective Practice .', 'Dating violence ( DV ) among young people is increasingly recognized as a significant problem and preventive effort targeting adolescent and young adult are being mobilized to tackle it .', 'However , an accumulating body of evidence show that these effort fail to adequately capture young people ’ s need , particularly those from diverse culture and contexts , and to incorporate their perspective into practice .', 'The present study aimed to address this gap by exploring young people ’ s view on how DV can be prevented and what they expect from prevention program in an urban Turkish context , where DV remains an under-studied issue and preventive effort are only slowly progressing .', 'Toward this goal , a qualitative research design was employed .', 'Thirty-nine college student , aged 18–25 , were recruited through convenience sampling and individually interviewed in a semi-structured manner .', 'The interview were transcribed and thematically analyzed from a social constructionist perspective .', 'The analysis revealed five main theme that indicated young people ’ s suggestion for and expectation from DV prevention : 1 ) setting new dating norm , 2 ) targeting socialization process , 3 ) improving relational competence , 4 ) improving oneself , and 5 ) managing obstacle .', 'The finding and practice implication are discussed within a contextual-ecological framework in the changing socio-cultural terrain of Turkey .', 'The study highlights the fact that young people ’ s view can guide the development of effective , contextually relevant , empowering , and collaborative practice , and indicates the value of listening to young people ’ s voice in the field of DV prevention .', 'Retrospective Analysis of Multidrug-resistant Pulmonary Tuberculosis Associated with Risk Factor in a Marginal Urban District .', 'To determinate a retrospective analysis of multidrug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis associated with risk factor in a marginal urban district Design : The type of research was observational and analytical , retrospective case and control .', 'The sample consisted of 40 case diagnosed with MDS TB by Sensitive Test ; for each case , two control were considered that were people who live in the same district , with a smear-positive diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis , pansensitives , that is , 80 control with FP-TB .', 'The data collection technique was the survey and the instrument , a questionnaire for both group ( case - control ) .', 'Result : Six internal and external risk factor associated with MDR TB were identified .', 'The internal risk factor associated with MDR TB were : previously receiving one or more treatment for tuberculosis , consumption of drug before having pulmonary TB and presence of a higher bacillary load in the BK result and pretreatment ( p < 0.05 ) culture ( +++ ) .', 'The external risk factor associated with MDR TB were : contact with a family member with MDR TB ; contact with friend or neighbor who died from TB and contact with someone with MDR TB outside the home ( p < 0.05 ) .', "Conclusion : The Factor : `` Presence of a higher bacillary load in the BK result and pretreatment culture ( +++ ) '' and `` Contact with someone you know with MDR TB outside the home '' are more significantly associated with MDR TB , if the incidence of these risk factor can be controlled , the progression of tuberculosis can be stopped .", "Implementing an mHealth app to combat hypertension in India 's vulnerable population .", 'Purpose : The purpose of this paper is to understand how to build and implement information and communication technology ( i.e .', 'ICT ) to help vulnerable people when significant social , cultural and economic barrier exist between the stakeholder .', "Design/methodology/approach : The author followed an action research approach to design and implement a mobile health hypertension education application to help India 's most vulnerable population .", 'The author used interpretive analysis , guided by the sustainable livelihood framework , to uncover key finding .', 'Finding : Successfully implementing information and communication technology for development ( ICT4D ) requires understanding that all stakeholder ( i.e .', 'donor , facilitator and the beneficiary ) have important asset to contribute .', 'Facilitator play an important role in connecting donor to the beneficiary and fostering cultural humility in donor so that the donor will understand the role beneficiary play in success .', "Stakeholder may use the ICT4D in unintended way that both improve the people 's health and increase some beneficiary ' financial livelihood .", 'Research limitations/implications : This research expands the definition of information system success when implementing ICT4D in resource-constrained environment .', 'Success is more than creating an mHealth app that was easy for beneficiary to use and where they learned based on a pre- and post-test statistical analysis .', 'Success involved development in all the stakeholder impacted by the social innovation collaboration .', 'For the beneficiary community , success included getting screened for noncommunicable disease as a first step toward treatment .', 'For the facilitator , success involved more resource for their community health program .', 'Amongst the donor , success was a change in perspective and learning cultural humility .', 'Practical implication : Although university encourage faculty to work in interdisciplinary research team to address serious world problem , university researcher may have to exert considerable effort to secure contract , approval and payment .', 'Unfortunately , university may not reward this effort to build ICT4D and continue to evaluate faculty based on journal publication .', 'When university undertake social innovation collaboration , administrator should ensure responsive and flexible university processes as well as appropriate academic reward structure are in place .', 'This need is heightened when collaboration involve international partner with limited resource and time needed to build relationship and understanding across culture .', 'Social implication : This study discovered the importance of fostering cultural humility as a way of avoiding potential conflict that may arise from cultural and power difference .', 'Cultural humility moves the focus of donor-beneficiary relationship away from getting comfortable with “ them ” to taking action that develop relationship and address vulnerability ( Fisher-Borne et al.', ', 2015 ) .', 'This research shows how the facilitator helped the donor develop cultural humility by involving the donor in various initiative with the beneficiary community including allowing the donor to live in a dormitory at the hospital , work in an urban slum and visit health screening campus .', 'Originality/value : This study ( 1 ) extends the ICT4D literature by incorporating cultural humility into the sustainable livelihood framework , ( 2 ) provides a contextual understanding of developing cultural humility in ICT4D project with a complex group of stakeholder and ( 3 ) describes how facilitator become a catalyst for change and a bridge to the community .', 'The culturally humble approach suggests revising the livelihood framework to eliminate word like “ the poor ” to describe beneficiary .', 'Association between dietary diversity and food insecurity in urban household : A cross-sectional survey of various ethnic population of Karachi , Pakistan .', 'Background and Purpose : The world is experiencing a nutritional transition , yet some region of South East Asia are still living under the shadow of catastrophic nutritional indicator .', 'Pakistan bears a high dual burden of both communicable and chronic disease .', 'However , a major contribut-ing factor of both is poor diet and nutrition .', 'The causal pathway of stunting , underweight , wasting , and micronutrient deficiency has beginning in less dietary diversity and food insecurity .', 'Current literature on Pakistan and other South Asian country regarding food insecurity and dietary diversity largely focus on woman and child aged less than 5 year ; however , ethnic and cultural dynamic of the populace concerning their food and dietary practice in Pakistan have not been well explored .', 'It is essential to have a clear insight into the factor involving malnutrition in different cluster , especially different culture and ethnicity to target specific area of interven-tional strategy versus a uniform approach for all .', 'This study aimed to explore the level of food insecurity and dietary diversity in all major ethnic group of Karachi , the largest city of Pakistan .', 'Method : Using the multistage random sampling , 535 household from five major ethnic group residing in Karachi were included in the study .', 'To measure food insecurity and dietary diversity ( primary and secondary outcome , respectively ) , we used a FAO standar-dized questionnaire ( version 3 , 2007 ) that was translated first into local language , piloted , and employed to collect information .', 'Result : Severe food insecurity level had an inverse relationship with the household dietary diversity , which persisted even after adjusting for other variable ( β=−0.31 , 95 % CI=−0.65 , −0.07 ) .', 'There was no statistically significant association of age , marital status , or education level on food diversity .', 'The most food secure cultural people were those whose ancestor had migrated from India and were Urdu speaking community , while Sindhi speaker were the least food secure community .', 'Conclusion : It is imperative to investigate more on the cultural causal factor leading to food insecurity to address the root cause of malnutrition and design new cultural-specific intervention that should be employed in large urban center where different community reside together .', "It looks and field note ( n = 15 ) .', "Result : Four theme emerged : 'you do n't have to worry ' ; ' a way of sharing knowledge ' ; 'it looks like a bread box ? Taylor & Francis Group .', 'Oko mama culture betel nut consuming habit in kupang district and its effect toward salivary ph and flow rate .', 'Public health always associated to culture and lifestyle .', 'Lifestyle itself constitutes a concept that commonly used to define “ The way people live ” , reflecting the whole social value , attitude , and activity .', 'One of long-term culture that become personal habit is chewing betel nut .', 'Oko Mama culture is the local culture of the Timorese tribe who consider it as the symbol of philosophy , dignity , enjoyment , beauty , also as a means of communication in society , political mean , and delaying hunger .', 'Several study revealed several unbeneficial of chewing betel nut , such as acute betel nut toxicity , cardiovascular disease , respiratory disorder , and congenital defect .', 'Besides , betel nut may also alter oral health .', 'This study is aiming to analyse the correlation of habitual chewing betel nut toward salivary pH and flow rate .', 'This was an observational analytic study , by mean of cross sectional design involving both on male and female aging 17-50 year old in 4 subdistrict , consisting of 2 remote area and 2 urban area .', 'The correlation between variable was analysed using path analysis by mean of Smart PLS 3.2.7 .', 'The analysis revealed a positive correlation between Oko Mama culture toward .', 'A positive correlation also recorded toward perceived norm ( p=0.931 ) .', 'While intention had a positive correlation toward behaviour ( p=0.429 ) .', 'Regarding oral health , chewing betel nut and coded for theme , first individually and then across all four .', 'Finding : Three theme emerged from the analysis .', 'According to the expert , the three most salient element for sustaining a of this study was to explore the perception of school principal and the experience of disclosure amongst teacher living with HIV .', 'Due to HIV/AIDS-related stigma being prevalent in many society is known to be a way of understanding experience .', 'Data was elicited via narrative interview from a purposeful sample of ten principal and eight teacher living with HIV who were selected through network sampling from Gauteng public urban school .', 'The study found that stigma , fear of job loss and gossip deterred teacher from disclosing their HIV status .', 'In some instance , they disclosed due to needing support , which principals provided in the form of counselling , and also to explain absenteeism .', 'Although principal supported disclosure of teacher ’ HIV status so that they could initiate care , confidentiality concern showed that disclosure could further worsen stigma and the culture of discrimination and moral judgement that teacher living with HIV faced .', 'The study recommends on-going development of caring relationship to deepen the understanding of the experience of teacher living with HIV .', 'Nondisclosure of HIV status stands in the way of building caring relationship between teacher and principal .', 'There is still a need to create safe , supportive and empathetic environment in school for teacher living with HIV .', 'Determinant of Exposure .', 'We employed a cross-sectional study design among a random sample of 243 participant .', 'The sociodemographic characteristic , education and training status , knowledge about route of exposure to Bacteria resistance to antibiotic was rising day by day misuse of antibiotic , therefore the use of antibiotic should be only by a qualified doctor prescription .', 'Prevention of disease the answer ..', 'The director general of the World Health Organization ( WHO ) , Hiroshi Nakajima , in an interview following a two-day visit to Rwanda stressed the need to restore safe blood transfusion service to prevent the spread of AIDS as well as distribution of essential drug and vaccine .', 'According to WHO , health facility were looted , while 75 % of the more than 5000 health worker fled or were killed since ethnic violence broke out April 6 , 1994 .', 'Fighting between the majority Hutu-led government and Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Front claimed more than 500,000 life and forced more than two million people to seek refuge in neighboring country .', 'The WHO will provide training , equipment , and laboratory supply in order to strengthen epidemiological monitoring of preventable epidemic disease like cholera , dysentery , acute respiratory infection , meningitis , tuberculosis , and malaria .', 'Of particular concern , was the need to monitor systematically form of cholera and bacillary dysentery which has the ability to change its resistance to different antibiotic A dysentery epidemic has already claimed thousand of life in refugee camp in Tanzania , Zaire and Rwanda .', 'War and massive population displacement have dramatically increased transmission of HIV , as HIV prevalence was about 30 % in Kigali among woman and up to 50 % among soldier .', 'Before the war , HIV infection rate ranged from 20 to 30 % among the urban population and less than 10 % in rural area .', 'More than 200,000 person were already infected with HIV in Rwanda in 1992 .', 'The WHO will provide blood transfusion kit to ensure collection , testing and transfusion of blood .', 'It will also train 60 blood transfusion technician .', 'The WHO will help to supply the management system of the Central Rwandan Pharmaceutical Office and provide essential drug and vaccine to supplement stock supplied by international donor .', 'Nakajima appealed to both the international community and Africa to help Rwanda .', "A tentative discussion on family planning problem in Xinjiang 's minority .", 'The Uighur Autonomous region in Xinjiang includes a number of minority group such as the Uighur , Kazakh and Hui .', 'The question of how to implement family planning in minority area if of utmost importance .', 'In February 1982 , the State Council decreed that family planning policy for minority group could justifiably be more lax than for the Han people , who comprise a majority of Chinese population .', 'Instead of advocating 1 child per couple , as is the current national policy , urban minority group are permitted 2 ( with exception , 3 ) child per couple and rural villager are permitted 3 ( with exception , 4 ) child .', 'The 1982 National Census showed that the natural rate of growth for Xinjiang was 13.63/1000 ( compared to the national rate of 11.45/1000 ) with individual minority growth rate as high as 20.11/1000 .', "The area 's gross output value can not keep up with this population increase .", "Over half of Xinjiang 's minority are of the Islamic faith , which teaches that birth are not self-willed .", 'It is crucial to inculcate in them that birth can indeed be planned .', 'Also , their custom of early marriage ( age 15 for girl and 16 for boy ) which leads to a high fertility rate , must be changed .', "Although Xinjiang 's land mass is great , only 38.4 % is arable , so the common belief that its population can grow without limit is fallacious .", 'When family planning was being implemented nationwide , for minority it was only propagandistic .', 'After the population growth for the majority Han was under control , the minority group declared family planning program would also benefit them .', 'Symposium were held contraceptive use became voluntary among many woman .', 'The birth rate fell from 22.5/1000 in 1981 to 14.09/1000 in 1985 .', 'Family planning also received approval from religious leader .', 'But because population distribution and growth are uneven in Xinjiang , family planning policy must reflect these difference .']

['The transnational capitalist class and contemporary architecture in globalizing city .', 'The focus of this article is on the role of the transnational capitalist class ( TCC ) in and around architecture in the production and marketing of iconic building and space , in global or world city .', 'The TCC is conceptualized in term of four fraction : ( 1 ) Those who own and/or and control the major transnational corporation and their local affiliate ( corporate fraction ) .', 'In architecture these are the major architectural , architecture-engineering and architecture-developer-real estate firm .', 'In comparison with the major global consumer good , energy and financial corporation the revenue of the biggest firm in the architecture industry are quite small .', 'However , their importance for the built environment and their cultural importance , especially in city , far outweighs their relative lack of financial and corporate muscle .', '( 2 ) Globalizing politician and bureaucrat ( state fraction ) .', 'These are the politician and bureaucrat at all level of administrative power and responsibility who actually decide what gets built where , and how change to the built environment are regulated .', '( 3 ) Globalizing professional ( technical fraction ) .', 'The member of this fraction range from the leading technician centrally involved in the structural feature of new building to those responsible for the education of student and the public in architecture .', '( 4 ) Merchant and medium ( consumerist fraction ) .', 'These are the people who are responsible for the marketing of architecture in all its manifestation .', '( There is obviously some overlap between the membership of these fraction . )', '.', 'My conclusion is that many global and aspiring global city have looked to iconic architecture as a prime strategy of urban intervention , often in the context of rehabilitation of depressed area .', 'The attempt to identify the agent most responsible for this transformation , namely the TCC , and to explain how they operate , suggests that deliberately iconic architecture is becoming a global phenomenon , specifically a central urban manifestation of the culture-ideology of consumerism .', 'Defining Suburbs .', 'There is no consensus as to what exactly constitutes a suburb .', 'This article examines the range of suburban definition in term of their structure and the topical issue that they grapple with .', 'Suburb have been defined according to many different dimension from location and transportation mode to culture and physical appearance .', 'Given this confusion , one approach is to abandon the term ; another is to use it with greater precision .', 'This is more than just an issue of semantics .', 'Rather how people talk and think about suburb shape how they can see such area being developed and redeveloped in the future .', 'Re-enchanting democracy as a mode of governance .', "In this article , I explore the contribution of governance micro-practices to the transformative co-production of policy process and political culture , drawing on experience of 'democracy-in-action ' in the finegrain practice of spatial planning and urban policy .", "Following an introduction , the first section introduces the tension which the design and practice of program in these field are called upon to negotiate , and the experimentation in both field which reaches towards more participative and 'people-centered ' way of working .", "I illustrate the challenge and potential for such transformation through two case of energetic civil society governance activity , one ( from north east England ) where old social democratic practice have lived on , and another ( from central Japan ) where more participative practice centered on people 's daily life concern have evolved .", 'I then outline a conception of a participative , pluralistic , richly-informed , people-centered polity , drawing on older contrast between elite and participative form of democracy .', "I argue that , in current time in country such as the UK , the new form of 'network governance ' which are appearing within and around the long-established design and practice of representative democracy hold a potential for more people-centered form to emerge .", 'How far such potential are realized , however , depends on contingent particularity and struggle .', 'I conclude by offering a range of hypothesis about quality to encourage in the particularity of micro-practices for those seeking to promote more progressive governance culture and resist regressive trajectory .', 'Urban history and cultural resource in urban regeneration : a case of creative waterfront renewal .', 'In recent decade , the role of culture and history has often become a driving factor in the process of urban regeneration .', 'The focus on culture and history as factor in regional transformation has been particularly extensive in response not only to competitiveness among city but also to sustainability requirement in the cultural sector .', 'In the same perspective of this approach , culture in its broadest sense assumes a decisive role in constructing a system of intervention where employment and social and sustainable development become the product of the integration of place , people , economy and tradition .', 'Creative city are currently working on how to improve the interaction between regeneration building , economic development and social renewal in order to achieve more comprehensive development of the city .', 'Existing creative city may be seen to revolve around the design , promotion and activation of urban area established due to their particular local characteristic .', 'Such area become creative cluster as a result of economic and structural innovation , related to the realization of innovator project achieved with the help of local development strategy based on the economy of excellence , culture and territorial quality .', 'Starting from such premise , this article aims to show the main factor which condition creativity in city - such as new policy , participation , history , place identity , cultural resource and sustainability - and an emblematic case study of creative regeneration .', 'This concerns the HafenCity district in Hamburg , where the history has assumed an important role in re-constructing the maritime identity and for many choice of urban nature .', 'Space , culture and urban design in late modernism and after .', 'Among the question underlying recent debate about the architecture of the city , two are perhaps more fundamental .', 'The first concerns the legitimacy of architectural practice : can we be assertive about how we should design our city without seeking to enforce social assumption which are ultimately authoritarian ?', 'The second concern architectural theory itself : can we be specific about what architecture does without being reductive about what society is ?', 'This article identifies and criticizes two kind of recent response to these question : the first is to defend an architecture of localism and containment in some new and some old way ; the second is to retreat into relativism , sometimes supported by the assertion that architecture is of limited consequence because society is increasingly independent of space .', 'The article defends the view that we can and must be assertive about the architecture of city in global rather than local term .', 'The experience of genuinely urban environment is about meeting , though not necessarily interacting with , other people , mostly unknown , who can be of recognizably different class , status , race or ethnic origin ; it is also about exploring the strange , and becoming aware of , though not necessarily participating in , other way of life .', '-from Author', 'Blue-collar creativity : Reframing custom-car culture in the imperilled industrial city .', "This paper hitches a ride with young car enthusiast to explore how their vehicle catalyse a unique form of vernacular creativity , in a seemingly imperilled industrial city setting.While television and print medium regularly demonise young driver for street racing and 'hoon ' behaviour , this paper purposely adopts a different perspective , on circuit of production and qualitative aspect of the urban custom-car design scene that constitute form of vernacular creativity .", 'Beyond moral panic little is known about movement , network , and linkage between custom car , young enthusiast , and urban space from which their activity emerge .', 'Utilising responsive , in-depth ethnographic method in Wollongong , Australia , this paper interprets custom-car design as vernacular creativity , valued by young people and located across unassuming and unheralded urban space .', "The possibility that custom-car designer possess skill that are asset for 'blue-collar ' industrial city is contrasted against a backdrop of wider discourse depicting such city as economically vulnerable , as 'victims ' of restructuringöand even 'uncreative ' .", 'Insight relevant to future research on the politics of planning , creative industry , and class identity are also discussed .', 'City and design .', 'City , initially a product of the manufacturing era , have been thoroughly remade in the image of consumer society .', 'Competitive spending among affluent household has intensified the importance of style and design at every scale and design profession have grown in size and importance , reflecting distinctive geography and locating disproportionately in city most intimately connected with global system of key business service .', "Meanwhile , many observer still believe good design can make positive contribution to people 's life .", 'ities and Design explores the complex relationship between design and urban environment .', 'It traces the intellectual root of urban design , presents a critical appraisal of the imprint and effectiveness of design profession in shaping urban environment , examines the role of design in the material culture of contemporary city , and explores the complex linkage among designer , producer and distributor in contemporary city , for example : fashion and graphic design in New York ; architecture , fashion and publishing in London ; furniture , industrial design , interior design and fashion in Milan ; haute couture in Paris and so on .', "This book offers a distinctive social science perspective on the economic and cultural context of design in contemporary city , presenting city themselves as setting for design , design service and the 'affect ' associated with design .", 'Light Night : An “ enlightening ” place marketing experience .', 'Purpose – The Light Night initiative currently under development in the UK offers an innovative approach to revitalising town and city centre by involving resident and visitor through culture and the art .', 'This initiative is based on the successful Nuit Blanche ( White Night ) culture/led urban revitalisation model tested in city like Brussels , Madrid , Montreal , Rome , São Paulo , Skopje and Toronto , where the Nuit Blanche programme alone resulted in an estimated $ 4.9 million economic impact on the city and attracted 800,000 people ( Toronto ) .', 'This paper aims to review element of good practice internationally in the implementation of this concept and suggest a way forward for its realisation in the UK .', 'Design/methodology/approach – This case study build on the 24/hour city concept and provides a practical example of how culture/led urban revitalisation through the Light Night programme can be implemented in Birmingham , Leeds , Liverpool , Nottingham and Sheffield based on successful international experience .', 'Finding – Evidence gathered through a review of the literature provided in this case study would suggest that community involvement through creative culture/led urban revitalisation initiative can be instrumental in developing sustainable place and community .', 'Furthermore , it may provide a pathway towards overcoming some of the negative perception associated with the night/time economy in many British town and city centre .', 'The Light Night programme provides an opportunity for key social stakeholder to implement this through its focus on shared culture , history and identity .', 'Originality/value – This paper reviews the evolution of the European Nuit Blanche initiative using a case study approach , and its interpretation in the UK through the Light Night programme .', 'It further explores the economic , cultural and social benefit of Light Nights and Nuit Blanche on community cohesion , tourism and regeneration .', 'This paper is of value to practitioner and policy/makers in place marketing , town centre management , local authority economic development officer , business manager , urban regeneration consultant , academic , tourism officer , community leader and town centre resident .', 'Designing difference : co-production of space of potentiality .', 'Design and Planning professional have long been influenced by the belief in physically and spatially deterministic power over people and the environment , a belief that their representation of space become space .', 'As a result the goal of design often becomes “ fixing ” or directing behavior and culture instead of letting culture happen .', 'This outlook often prevents designer from engaging critically with culture , through representational space and spatial practice , as a crucial , possibly the most crucial , aspect in the design process .', 'Just as human culture interact to constantly reproduce and co-produce hybrid culture , the professional designer and those user and experiencers of design ( at whatever scale ) must interact to co-produce space and place of activity .', 'Through a critique of the practice of placemaking , we highlight the need to differentiate between participation and co-production .', 'Understanding participation as one element of the design process and the role of design at larger scale of co-productive process can help designer have a better understanding of how space are produced , and the role of designer in the creation of space of potentiality .', 'Agam-ben ’ s writing on potentiality and Lefebvre ’ s spatial triad offer a theoretical framework to investigate the ethical role of professional designer in society while taking a critical stance against the singular solution of modernist urban transformation .', 'Space of Potentiality are seen here as a designer ’ s simultaneous withdrawal from rational problem solving and deterministic solution , and an engagement with open source strategy for the co-production of urban space .', "Steering clear of politics : Local virtue in Helsinki 's design activism .", 'Practical project around the world are exploring and prefiguring ecologically feasible future .', 'The idea informing these initiative are familiar from degrowth discourse .', "But particularly where activist hail from the professional middle-classes of wealthy cities-architects , designer and other 'creatives ' in Helsinki for example-they risk being dismissed by the medium as well as by academic as vacuous life-style experimenter .", "Looking at Finland , the sense that this activity is not truly political or transformative can be further enhanced by activist ' own reluctance to enter into explicitly political debate and their preference for discussing future in the neutral language of science .", "Connecting today 's situation to precursor in the 1960s , however , we can see how these local project are embedded in local political culture , including a Finnish tendency to play up scientific rationality as a tool for managing collective affair .", 'This contrast with many other degrowth discourse shows the significance of local history in influencing the space available for people to work out alternative to the status quo .', 'Spatial culture : Towards a new social morphology of city past and present .', 'What is the relationship between how city work and what city mean ?', 'Spatial Culture : Towards a New Social Morphology of Cities Past and Present announces an innovative research agenda for urban study in which theme and method from urban history , social theory and built environment research are brought into dialogue across disciplinary and chronological boundary .', 'The collection confronts the recurrent epistemological impasse that arises between research focussing on the description of material built environment and that which is concerned primarily with the people who inhabit , govern and write about city past and present .', 'A reluctance to engage substantively with this issue has been detrimental to scholarly effort to understand the urban built environment as a meaningful agent of human social experience .', 'Drawing on a wide range of historical and contemporary urban case study , as well as a selection of theoretical and methodological reflection , the contribution to this volume seek to historically , geographically and architecturally contextualize diverse spatial practice including movement , encounter , play , procession and neighbourhood .', 'The aim is to challenge their tacit treatment as universal category in much writing on city and to propose alternative research possibility with implication as much for urban design thinking as for history and the social science .', 'From designed space to designer savvy society : The potential of idea competition in willing participation .', 'The design of public space has gained importance as city are increasingly positioned in global flow of people , capital , and idea .', 'These space speak to the culture of a place as much as to the quality of its design , but the implementation of design as an inclusive process is fraught with difficulty .', "This is particularly pertinent in discussion about better way of engaging people with urban design , where there is often a language barrier between those who specialise in spatial manipulation and the broader 'society ' that uses this space .", 'This paper gives an empirical account of how a spatial consciousness can be translated to society through an international design competition .', "The competition method of urban design relies upon promotion and 'eventfulness ' , both of which interpolate the public and contribute towards the generation of a deeper interest in the spatial imaginary of city planning .", "The creation of 'urban design consumer ' through the visual consumption of the design themselves offers an alternative way to gain public interest to the established tradition of public notice and formal public meeting .", "In this case , the competition extended the activity of urban designer beyond the mechanic of 'space production ' to include 'consumer production ' where a more intimate relationship between city planning and the people began to emerge .", 'Welcome city : Refugee in three German city .', 'Since late 2015 , the author have studied the refugee crisis in Europe .', 'In this article , we analyze local factor that are significant for urban planning to include in an integration plan through case study in three city in Germany .', 'We have chosen to study Germany because of the country ’ s touted Willkommen Kultur ( welcome culture ) , which was prompted in large part by Chancellor Angela Merkel ’ s “ Flüchtlinge Willkommen ” ( “ refugee welcome ” ) stance .', 'Now , three year after Chancellor Merkel ’ s declaration to the world , although international and national policy set many parameter for refugee integration , responses to the uncertainty of the situation are fundamentally informed by local contexts .', 'Germany has adopted a policy of distributing refugee to community throughout the country according to the so-called “ Königstein Key ” , which sets quota for each state according to economic capacity .', 'We have selected case study city and a county that are at different scale and region : Borken in Hessen ( 13,500 people ) , Kassel County ( 200,000 ) , and Essen , a larger city ( 600,000 ) .', 'Here we investigate the way in which German citizen and refugee interact and integrate , with a focus on the social-spatial aspect of refugee experience and the impact on urban planning policy , urban morphology , building typology , and pattern language formation .', 'Beyond crisis , we are looking at how refugee can and will try to integrate into their host country , city , and neighborhood and start a new life and how host community respond to refugee arrival .', 'Urban architecture project for housing and work opportunity that help the process of integration are part of this study .', 'Particularly , in this article , we investigate the reality on the ground of the positive Willkommen Kultur and the high expectation and implied promise that were set in 2015 by Chancellor Angela Merkel and German society .', 'The temptation of nationalism in modern capital city .', 'In a world riven by ethnic , racial , and nationalist conflict , there is much appeal to the idea that city might be able to transcend the pressure of their embed-dedness in nation-states , and that an urban-centered identity could rally less destructive sort of allegiance .', "One promising venue for testing such claim is the capital city , since-by definition-such place need to represent the seat of government and other `` national '' institution .", 'At the same time , capital city are not equivalent to nation-states ; they are still separately identifiable as city , even though they are certainly city of a very specialized kind .', "The act of designing a new capital city-or building significant new `` national '' institution in an existing capital city-forces an engagement with question of national representation.1 Specifically , how are multiple social identity constructed through architecture and urban design ?", 'And , if such constructed identity matter , which group in a plural society see themselves as represented in what gets built to represent supposedly national institution ?', 'Does a capital city represent an opportunity to provide an alternative to nationalist discourse and subnational division , or does it serve to reinforce the sense that some people are included in the conception of the nation-state much more so than others ?', 'In this chapter , I attempt to argue three thing : 1 .', "A wide variety of regime have used urban design and architecture to advance a nationalist agenda , and this `` design politics '' operates at all visible scale .", '2 .', 'When such regime give in to the temptation of nationalism , the result are usually very divisive .', '3 .', 'Conversely , it is possible to imagine way that architecture and urban design can be used to heal political rift .', "Ernest Gellner , in his book Nations and Nationalism , defines nationalism as `` a theory of political legitimacy '' which holds that `` the political and the national unit should be congruent '' ( Gellner 1983 , 1 ) .", "In other word , the political unit-what we generally call the nation-state , or more informally the `` country '' -and the national unit should coincide exactly if they are superimposed .", 'The problem is that the world is not organized this way , largely due to a long history of empire and colonialism , not to mention a variety of supranational political and economic alliance .', 'If , as one extreme example demonstrates , one compares a map of Africa subdivided according to the border of nation-states with a map showing the far more fine-grained subdivision of ethnic group that fall both within and across the boundary of many nation-states , the two bear little resemblance and help explain major internal and international tension .', 'It is true that the system of African nation-states is far more equitable than the coarse grain of the imperially divided spoil that characterized the map of the earlier colonized continent , but the legacy of a continent fragmented by the will of European colonist still suffers from the legacy of irrationally imposed border .', 'The modern system of nation-states-built mostly in the last two century ( and especially during the last sixty year , a time when the number of nation-states has more than tripled ) has not been easily superimposed on the system of ethnically defined nation or would-be nation , many of which find themselves to be subdivision ( or minority group within ) a nation-state that they do not recognize as legitimate .', 'In short , the map that depict people do not correspond very well with the map that depict place .', "If one turns to a reputable source like the newest American Heritage Dictionary , which is often serviceable for most purpose ( though even that book 's name seems to raise additional question about this very topic ) , the proffered definition of nationalism seem at least as evasive or incomplete as Gellner 's .", "In the first instance , according to the American Heritage , nationalism denotes `` devotion to the interest or culture of one 's nation . ''", "What is not said , of course , is that `` nation '' in this sense may not exactly coincide with one 's nation-state .", 'In other word , nationalism can often be about devotion to some subnational portion of a pluralist nation-state that is attempting to harness and discipline many constituent nation within it .', "Nationalism can also be counter-posed to internationalism , as when the dictionary defines it as `` the belief that nation will benefit from acting independently rather than collectively , emphasizing national rather than international goal . ''", "Finally , nationalism may denote `` aspiration for national independence in a country under foreign domination . ''", 'This latter aspect seems particularly important , since it implies that nationalism is not necessarily tied to some fixed moment in political history .', "There is a nationalism of aspiration-embraced by those who do not yet control a nation-state but think that they should-as well as a nationalism of consolidation-championed by those who do control a nation-state but are struggling to make sure that the aspiring nation within its border do not succeed in undermining the state 's sovereign legitimacy .", "What I refer to as the `` temptation of nationalism '' in the title of this chapter is largely focused on the latter kind of nationalism .", "For those that are still aspiring to become nation-states , `` the temptation of nationalism '' is no more than an obvious tautology .", 'For nation-states struggling to maintain their political hold on their constituent people ( or to extend their hold onto adjacent territory ) , however , this nationalism of consolidation is both urgent and difficult to construct .', 'Nationalism in this sense is a two-stage proposition : the first stage-the nationalism of aspiration-supports a drive for independence in the name of freedom and self-determination , and the second stage-the nationalism of consolidation-is what is needed to define the self that has been freed .', "As political scientist Crawford Young puts it , the state which , before independence , had been the `` foil against which unity was forged '' is , after independence , `` itself the main vehicle in the hand of the nationalist elite for the fulfillment of the mission '' ( Young 1978 , 71 ) .", 'In other word , nationalist movement begin as struggle against the state but , if they succeed , they suddenly have to become the state , themselves .', 'Because the hold on power is uncertain , the leader of a nation-state are tempted to take nationalistic position that endeavor to suppress or supersede pre-independence subnational identity that are not useful to the dominant group in power .', 'The temptation of nationalism is the promise of unity and legitimacy , the dream of a consolidated nation-state unchallenged by those who would unravel it or secede .', 'Project , program and event as potential future-forming city identity asset : Linking practice to reflexivity , selected urban outdoors lighting manifestation in decade , the paper aims to provide stimulus to convert them into a coherent strategic line of development .', 'Based on postmodern epistemology , the author of this paper propose an analysis of selected lighting manifestation as separated future-forming moment of city identity .', 'The adoption of a future research matrix as a reflexive framework sees the repurposing of such a framework from given future scenario .', 'With the final outcome proposed as to coherently connect separate , lighting-related , manifestation to an overarching system of interpretation .', 'The case offered is the city of Eindhoven , The Netherlands .', 'The tool adopted and repurposed is the Urban Futures Matrix from city.people.light .', 'The specific manifestation , as presented , pertain both high culture and popular culture .', 'This paper does eminently offer a coherent and consistent reflection on practice in the form of a case study , however , grounded in a theoretical and epistemological solid framework of reference .', 'The cultural industry : An introduction .', 'Twenty year ago publishing a book on the cultural industry would first , no doubt , demand some kind of reckoning with Adorno ’ s monolithic Culture Industry .', 'One might point to their pluralisation and fragmentation - into the cultural industry - alongside continuing process of agglomeration and concentration .', 'It would involve recognition of their more contradictory and ambiguous relationship to those wider process of power and control articulated within and through their structure and product .', 'This work of retrieval and complication , done under the broad rubric of the political economy of culture , communication and/or medium , had been under way in North America , France and the United Kingdom ( UK ) since the 1970s ( Mosco , 1996 ) .', 'Unlike other approach - notably that of cultural study - the political economy approach was less concerned with the high/low , art/commerce distinction than it was with the role of medium and communication system in the reproduction of a complex modern ( capitalist ) society .', 'It wanted to know how , and on what ground , might the modern democratic state organise or regulate such a system , and what complex social , economic and political consideration needed to be made in the light of this .', 'It was very much engaged - not implacably opposed but engaged - in the heated debate about the de-or re-regulation of the broadcast medium and new kind of commercial and public sector channel coming into being across the 1990s ( Hesmondhalgh , 2013a ) .', 'Elsewhere the reckoning with the Culture Industry took a local turn .', 'A book on the cultural industry in the mid-1990s might evoke an eclectic new set of producer and intermediary who mixed art , popular culture , technology and a kind of streetwise entrepreneurialism quite tangential to the formal structure of the art funding system ( Wynne and O ’ Connor , 1996 ; Leadbeater and Oakley , 1999 ) .', 'Community art and new social movement combined with a contemporary popular culture ( animated by the spirit of cultural study ) to embrace an urbanism re-emerging from under the rusted hulk of the Fordist city ( Bianchini and Parkinson , 1993 ) .', 'These announced a new potential for local re-invention .', 'By the mid-1990s consultancy and local government report in the UK were identifying this new breed of cultural producer as being in possession of the kind of quality required for a transformed city - a city with the potential to take its future in its own hand , no longer determined by the accident of geography and geology .', 'Autopoesis rather than autonomy was the watchword , as endogenous growth based on re-inventing and mobilising existing strength became an alternative to the disempowering script of attracting mobile global capital .', 'Though often thought of as some kind of economism or instrumentalism by which the art sector attempted to protect its shrinking funding base , the cultural industry at local level tried to diffuse the structuring tension between culture and economy .', 'As culture was becoming more important economically so too ‘ economics ’ ( though the discipline was lagging behind the reality perhaps ) was finally acknowledging the reality of culture .', 'The cultural industry might not be the whole solution to the question raised by the socio-economic transformation of the post-industrial city , but whatever the solution there was little doubt culture would be part of it .', 'Nicholas Garnham - involved in the experiment of the Greater London Council 1979-86 ( Garnham , 1990 ) - linked these political economy and urban development strands together : both contemporary democracy and democratic cultural policy at multiple scale demanded an engagement with the reality of the production , distribution and consumption of culture .', 'It is less likely that such a book - in the Anglophone world at least - would acknowledge that they were in the middle ( 1988-97 ) of the World Decade for Culture and Development ( WCCD , 1996 ) .', 'Emerging out of a number of United Nations umbrella organisation - in particular the United Nations Educational , Scientific and Cultural Organization ( UNESCO ) - the ‘ culture and development ’ tradition emphasised both the cultural context in which development necessarily took place and the value articulated by this culture as a crucial benchmark of a qualitatively human rather than technocratic development process ( Arizpe , 2004 ; De Beukelaer , 2015 ; Isar , this volume ) .', 'In this the cultural industry , conceived as a modern cultural infrastructure of production , distribution and consumption , were crucial both to nation building and protecting local identity in the face of a globalising culture .', 'Growing out of the failure of the NewWorld Information and Communications Order ( UNESCO , 1980 ; Mosco , 1996 ; Singh , 2011 ) , the cultural turn in development study ( as generally in the social science ) and post-colonial and post-development literature , ‘ culture and development ’ combined both an anthropological and a political economy approach to cultural industry .', 'However , in the metropolitan heartland , worried by the domestic employment impact of the re-location of manufacturing to the ‘ developing world ’ , the cultural industry appeared primarily as a developed world option .', 'Ten year on and the landscape had changed considerably .', 'First the creative industry , and then creative economy , had either replaced or been bolted on to the cultural industry : cultural and creative , or cultural creative .', 'Many at the time saw this as a purely pragmatic title change , or were ‘ what ’ s in a name ’ agnostic ; it was not immediately clear how the replacement of ‘ cultural ’ by ‘ creative ’ worked both to preserve and to expunge element traditionally associated with ‘ culture ’ .', '‘ Creativity ’ as an input ( rather than culture as an output ) allowed the imaginative , dynamic , transformative and glamorous aspect of culture to be pressed into the service of an innovation machine .', 'Question of value other than innovation and other economic impact were dropped .', 'That this was not immediately apparent says a lot about the cultural industry ‘ imaginary ’ ( s ) of the mid-1990s , which should neither be reduced to a simple ‘ precursor ’ of the creative industry nor viewed as a radically distinct set of idea and aspiration ( O ’ Connor , 2013 ) .', 'In general , the kind of loose coalition that pursued the creative industry agenda grew out of those involved in the cultural industry .', 'They were concerned with cultural small and medium size enterprise ( SMEs ) and entrepreneurs , regenerating city and region , programming new kind of mixed use cultural space , setting up local development agency , re-tooling higher and further education course , developing training programme and sometimes , via the relevant culture or trade ministry , trying to influence legislation or gain political legitimation .', 'Three development altered this easy continuity .', 'First came the explosion of the Internet and digital and computing technology generally , with their reconfiguration of the established nature of , and connection between , cultural production , texts and audience .', 'The UK government ’ s addition of computing and information and communication technology ( ICT ) to the ‘ creative industry ’ list in 1998 has been frequently commented on ( Garnham , 2005 ; Tremblay , 2011 ) .', 'Not only did it boost the employment number , often by around 40 per cent , but it worked to subsume the cultural ( now creative ) sector under the rubric of the knowledge economy .', 'Many promoting the cultural industry had already positioned culture as part of the knowledge economy but its imaginary had shifted from that of a city or region able to re-invent itself through resource of culture towards the capacity to release the heroic entrepreneurial energy eulogised by the Californian ideology .', 'It seemed incontrovertible that the ‘ digital revolution ’ was transforming the land- scape of ( what had been ) the cultural industry , pulling the plug on their business model , bringing in new entrant , transforming the way audience interacted , purchased and adapted cultural texts .', 'In this light the creative industry , with their horizontal network , co-creative practice , and open-ended texts providing digital affordances for the creative citizen-consumer , could be seen to incarnate ( and make redundant ) many of the transformative aspiration of the cultural industry ( Hartley , 2005 ) .', 'The creative industry announced a new kind of economy that drew on cultureinflected creativity within a ( transformed ) commercial sector that was as far away from Adorno ’ s Culture Industry as one could possibly imagine .', 'At the same time - given the radical flattening of hierarchy and the infinite creativity of the consumer - it could simply sidestep the dour stricture of political economy .', 'Second came Richard Florida ’ s creative class , which seemed to encapsulate - and indeed statistically nail - the broad connection between culture and the future of the post-industrial city that had emerged in the 1990s ( Florida , 2002 ) .', 'The simplicity of the idea - build ‘ cool ’ , ‘ edgy ’ place in the city as amenity to attract artist and cultural worker , scientist and technician , senior management and professional - has both been routinely denounced and phenomenally successful ( Peck , 2010 ) .', 'Florida ’ s opening out of arts-led regeneration to embrace hip , popular and everyday culture ( lifestyle ) was welcomed as a democratic move .', 'It also made the space of cool consumption - and of course local city could insert almost any new development into this space - a synecdoche for the wider creativity of the city ( even though the real economy might lie elsewhere ) .', 'It was this unspecified - yet seemingly statistically demonstrable - catalytic connection between a trendy consumption infrastructure and the overall creativity of the city that proved irresistible to the elected official - if not the cultural manager - of many otherwise sensible city .', 'The third change was perhaps the most surprising - certainly for the agency that had come up with the term in the first place .', 'Soon after the Department for Culture , Media and Sport ( DCMS ) launched the ‘ creative industry ’ idea in 1998 , it was taken up by the very East Asian country - or ‘ economy ’ as they had become known - from whose manufacturing prowess these new industry were meant to allow the postindustrial country to escape .', 'Singapore , South Korea , Hong Kong , Taiwan and eventually China enthusiastically embraced the creative industry as the next step up the value chain ( Wang , 2004 ; O ’ Connor and Gu , 2006 ; Kong et al.', ', 2006 ; Keane , 2007 ) .', 'Taking seriously the evolutionary schema that was mostly political rhetoric in the UK - from a manufacturing to a service to a creative economy - these East Asian nation , also unlike the UK , put their money where their mouth were .', 'In so doing they took seriously the notion of creative industry as intellectual property ( IP ) intensive and thus included in their list bio-tech , pharmaceutical , software and computing , product design , consulting and other advanced business service .', 'They split them off from culture - which ( somewhat off message ) they saw as involving non-economic value - and subjected them to the kind of ‘ catch-up ’ strategy they had earlier applied to advanced manufacture and other high-value added industry .', 'This created unexpected opportunity for agent such as the British Council - the brand leader - as western know-how was sought for these emergent industry .', 'What they got was not quite what they wanted .', 'Creativity and entrepreneurialism was very much linked to the artistic persona - the maverick , the rebel , the non-wearing of a suit .', 'It also depended on notion of open , loose but high trust network of SMEs that - according to the rhetoric at least - marked the kind of creative economy emerging in the West .', 'What East Asia wanted were industry strategy , foreign direct investment , value chain analysis , brand management , market structuring and so on .', 'These were rarely available from western cultural agency who masked the complete absence of any kind of capacity , or willingness , for an industry strategy in the rhetoric of unplanned , market-driven creativity , where the job of the state was to get out of the way .', 'These kind of cultural-creative initiative continue to operate in East Asia out of the various office of the British Council and similar agency from Germany , the Low Countries and Scandinavia .', 'But they were residential landscape ( Gelezeau 1999 , 2003 ) .", 'Similarly , other study have traced the rise of youth subculture starting in the early 1990s that specifically address aspect of alienation and urban overload among the middle class ( Epstein 2000 ; Epstein and Tangherlini 2002 ) .', 'Because of these rapid change in the man-made environment and the simultaneous urbanization of the population , community structure were profoundly altered .', 'Consequently , pattern of socialization and interaction have been adapted to this urban environment , and site of leisure , such as Lotte World , have taken on an important function beyond their obvious role as place where thing are bought and sold .', "At Lotte World , for instance , middle school and high school student reaffirm important peer relationship while waiting in line for the flume ride , parent bond with young child while watching the Lotty and Lorry parade , grandparent interact informally with their grandchild while tossing wooden stick in a traditional game of yutnori at the folklore museum , colleague solidify work relationship while fine-tuning their golf swing at the indoor driving range , and friend discuss everyday concern while bargain hunting on the subterranean `` Trevi Fountain '' plaza .", 'All of these activity highlight connectedness and are integral to aspect of urban socialization , community formation , and enculturation .', "They also constitute important `` authentic '' experience of the urban middle class , even if the surroundings are decidedly `` inauthentic . ''", 'People enjoy the replicas - of building , of place , of historical time , and of experience - but are not for a minute fooled by them ; the kid on the flume ride are well aware they are riding a flume ride in Lotte World , and not coursing down a tributary to the Amazon in a dugout canoe .', 'This abandonment of an overarching concern with an external authentic referent is a crucial development .', "Earlier themed space stretching back to Skansen and Maihaugen in Scandinavia and the cultural exhibition of the world 's fair often strove for mimetic representation of foreign place or the past ( Bendix 1997 ; Kirshenblatt-Gimblett 1998 ; Sandberg 2003 ; Tangherlini 2008 ) .", 'By rejecting these earlier form of authenticity , the mall and the theme park now emphasize consumption and efficiency .', 'An interesting aspect of this shift away from the external logic of authenticity is the increasing role that consumption play as a backdrop for activity such as family bonding or other type of community formation .', "Rather than casting a wistful eye away to the `` foreign '' or back in time toward the older and therefore more `` authentic , '' as implicit in earlier theme park and museum display , the current park - and shopping mall for that matter - embrace the notion that all experience are authentic .", 'Susan Davis note , `` Unlike the rock concert , and more like the shopping mall , the theme park depends on the construction of a landscape and the careful planning of human movement through space .', "The spatial rationale of the theme park is to cluster commercial opportunity - from hot dog stands to designer boutique - around attraction which can range from ride to human or animal or robotic performance '' ( 1996 , 403 ) .", "Mark Gottdiener continues , observing that these `` themed environment work not only because they are connected to the universe of commodity and are space of consumption , but because they offer consumer a spatial experience that is an attraction by itself ; that is , they promote the consumption of space '' ( 1998 , 15 ) .", 'I can think of few place where this is more apparent than at Lotte World .', 'The shopping mall-cum-theme park and the theme park-cum- shopping mall are clearly related phenomenon , not only in their physical design but also as product of similar historical process .', 'Both are loci of interrelated consumption , and both offer an important window onto how the middle class life .', 'Although the lifestyle of the Korean middle class have become an object of increasing academic interest ( Hart 2001 ; Kendall 2002 ; Moon 1997a ; Nelson 2000 ) , the majority of the scholarly study of theme park and shopping mall has been directed at North American example or , in some limited case , on Western European analog ( Backes 1997 ; Bloch , Ridgway , and Dawson 1994 ; Kowinski 1985 ; Sandicki and Holt 1998 ; Sherry 1998 ; Vester 1996 ) .', "Joy Hendry 's work exploring the wide range of theme park that have cropped up in Japan marks a welcome departure from this theoretical homogeneity ( 2000a ) .", "She proposes that `` contextualized cultural description '' might be a interpretive model would be equally irresponsible .', "Writing about the advent of enormous shopping mall/theme park complex in Southeast Asia , Alyson Brody observes that `` in the space-restricted , developed in an old milk factory in Milan .', 'The proposal is part of a PhD research programme with the aim of developing a solution that enhances the growth and development of Creative Place for a
